Such certification forms shall be returned by all participating veterinarians to the county animal control unit. The city's animal control unit shall secure and distribute to all county veterinarians and any other requesting veterinarians outside the county, at cost, tags to be attached to the collar or harness of all dogs and cats. All tags distributed shall be sequentially numbered and shall contain the name of the county where issued. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-88, 6-13-2006) Secs. 8-90—8-106. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RESTRAINT
Sec. 8-107. - Maintenance of areas. It shall be the duty of the owner of property to maintain in a reasonably clean and sanitary condition, and free from extreme and unreasonably objectionable odor, all structures, pens, yards and areas adjacent thereto, wherein any animal is kept. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-111, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-108. - Animals creating nuisances. The owner of any animal which allows such animal to habitually bark, whine, howl or cause other objectionable noise, or which allows any animal to cause serious annoyance to a neighboring residence or interfere with the reasonable use or enjoyment of a neighbor's property, or which is otherwise offensive in any manner is deemed to create a nuisance and is, therefore, unlawful. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-112, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-109. - Animal or fowl enclosures. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any domestic animal, fowl or livestock except under the following conditions: (1) Any housing or enclosure used by any domestic animal, fowl or livestock shall be well drained, free from accumulations of animal excrement and objectionable odors and otherwise reasonably clean and sanitary. (2) Animal excrement shall be disposed of in a manner approved by a health officer designated by the board of health. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-113, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-110. - General confinement of animals, vicious animals, etc. (a) Confinement of dogs. An owner of a dog, whether vaccinated or not vaccinated, shall confine such dog within an adequate fence or enclosure or within a house, garage or other building, or shall confine such dog by a chain, cable or leash affixed to the dog's collar and attached to some substantial stationary object adequate to prevent the dog from running at-large. (b) Control of dogs when off owner's premises. When a dog is off the premises of the owner, the dog must be controlled by means of a leash. The leash shall not be more than six feet in length and the dog shall be controlled by a competent person. (c) Preventing dogs or cats from becoming a danger or from trespassing. An owner of a dog or cat, whether vaccinated or not vaccinated, shall prevent such dog or cat from becoming a danger to persons or property at any location, or trespassing upon another person's property without that person's permission. (d) Preventing dog from running at-large. An owner of a dog, whether vaccinated or not vaccinated, shall prevent such dog from running at-large upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or public places in the city. (e) Impoundment/confinement of animals which attack without provocation. An animal, whether vaccinated or not vaccinated, not under control as provided in this chapter which attacks or attempts to attack without provocation a human being or domestic animal is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be impounded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and/or ordered confined by the animal control unit for a period of up to 30 days, provided that if an action is brought in any court of competent jurisdiction concerning the attack or attempt to attack by such animal, the period of confinement may be extended until the entry of a final order of disposition in such action. (f) Confinement of vicious animals. An owner of a vicious animal, whether vaccinated or not vaccinated, shall confine it within a building or secure enclosure and not release it there from unless it is securely muzzled and under restraint. Any vicious animal not under control as provided in this chapter is hereby declared a nuisance and may be impounded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and/or confined by the animal control unit for a period of up to 30 days, provided that if an action is brought in any court of competent jurisdiction concerning the attack or attempt to attack by such animal, the period of confinement may be extended until the entry of a final order of disposition in such action. (g) Confinement of female dogs or cats in heat. Every female dog or cat in heat shall be kept confined in a building or secure enclosure or in a veterinary clinic or hospital or in a kennel in such a manner that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another dog or cat, except for intentional breeding purposes. (h) Entrance into food places prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any owner to allow such owner's dog or cat to enter any food store, restaurant or place where food is exhibited for sale except those animals trained for the blind, hearing impaired, handicapped and law enforcement. (i) Fowl, livestock, etc., prohibited from running at-large. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having control of any chickens, ducks, horses, cows, goats, pigs or any other type of animal, livestock or other fowl within the city to permit them to run at-large or be a menace or nuisance to such person's neighbors or the public in general. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-114, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-111. - Rabid animals or animals suspected of having rabies. (a) Every veterinarian shall report promptly to the state department of human resources and the animal control unit all cases of rabies in animals treated by such veterinarian, giving the names and addresses of the owner of any animals bitten by such rabid animal, so far as known. (b) Any person who knows that an animal, domestic or wild, is rabid or suspects an animal of having rabies, or knows that an animal has been bitten by a rabid animal, shall promptly report such information to the state department of human resources and the animal control unit. (c) It shall be the duty of the owner, the health department, physicians, hospitals or other persons or agencies gaining information that any domestic animal or person has been bitten or is probably infected with rabies to notify the animal control unit, which will impound the animal where the animal shall be held for observation for such period of time as may be reasonably necessary to determine whether the animal is infected with rabies. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-115, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-112. - Heads of rabid animals to be submitted for examination. The heads of all animals having had rabies or which were suspected of having had rabies at the time of their deaths shall be submitted to the animal control unit for examination. These specimens will be collected and delivered to the proper authorities by the animal control unit. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-116, 6-13-2006) Secs. 8-113—8-137. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CRUELTY[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4.
Sec. 8-138. - Prohibited treatment. It shall be unlawful for any person, either by commission or omission: (1) To confine an animal in a vehicle in an inhumane manner such that the animal becomes overheated or lacks adequate ventilation or is otherwise harmed. (2) For any owner to fail to provide any animal under his control with proper veterinary care. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "owner" shall mean any person, legal entity, corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owning, possessing, or having custody and control of the premises where the animal is located. (3) To fail to provide any animal under his care with access to shelter consisting of not less than three walls, flooring other than ground and a roof adequate to protect it from all types of weather, 24 hours daily. (4) To abandon any animal. (5) To keep or confine an animal under his control in other than a humane manner. Sec. 8-162. - Permit. (a) Required. No person shall operate an animal establishment without first obtaining a permit from the animal control unit in compliance with this chapter, nor may any person operate an animal establishment in a manner in violation of any provision of this chapter. (b) Duration of permit; renewals; applications for new businesses. The permit period shall begin with the first day of the calendar year and shall run for one year. Renewal application for permits shall be made within 30 days prior to January 1 of each year. Application for a permit for a new establishment under the provisions of this chapter shall be made within five days of the start of business or operation. (c) Every facility considered separate enterprise. Every facility regulated by this article shall be considered a separate enterprise requiring an individual permit (e.g., two kennels at different locations but owned by the same person shall be considered as two animal establishments). (d) Display of permits. Permits obtained in accordance with this article shall be displayed in a prominent location on the premises of the animal establishment. (e) Business licenses required. Permits obtained in accordance with this article in no way relieve the animal establishment owner of the responsibility of obtaining a business license under section 38-104. (f) Selling, bartering or gratuitously distributing animals prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or gratuitously distribute any animal, fowl or reptile in a public place without a license or permit as set forth in this article. This prohibition shall include, but not be limited to, such distribution in commercial areas and along public roadways. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the gratuitous distribution of pets from private residential areas. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-191, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-163. - Permit application procedure. (a) Filing requirement. The animal control unit shall either issue or decline to issue a permit to the applicant. Any animal establishment denied a permit may not reapply for a period of at least 30 days. Each reapplication shall describe any previous denial or revocation. (f) Denial or revocation of permit for withholding information. If an applicant is shown to have withheld or falsified any material information on any application, the animal control unit may refuse to issue or is entitled to revoke any permit. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-192, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-164. - Revocation of permits. No. 2006-06, § 14-193, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-165. - Compliance with Code. All pet shops, including pet shops operated in conjunction with another holding facility, shall in addition to the other requirements of this chapter comply with the minimum standards of this section. No. 2006-06, § 14-202, 6-13-2006) Secs. 8-174—8-199. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - ANIMAL-DRAWN VEHICLES
Sec. 8-200. - Health of the animal. No animal shall be permitted to pull any carriage unless the animal is in good health and meets at least the following requirements: (1) All draft animals must weigh at least 1,000 pounds. (2) The animal must have no major open sores or wounds and must not be lame or have any other ailment, unless a veterinarian states in writing that the animal shall not be affected unduly by the proposed work. (3) The hooves of the animal must be properly shod and trimmed. (4) The animal must be groomed daily and not have fungus, dandruff or a poor or dirty coat. (5) The animal must have adequate flesh and muscle tone. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-221, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-201. - Animal working conditions. (a) No animal shall be worked under any of the following conditions: (1) No animal shall be permitted to draw a carriage equipped with ball bearing wheels which hauls more than 12 people (including the driver) or a carriage equipped with bushing wheels which hauls more than nine people (including the driver). (2) Total hours worked may not exceed eight in any 24-hour period with 15-minute rest periods between each trip, if the animal is used to haul people or goods. (3) Between the dates of June 1 and August 31, total hours worked by any animal shall not exceed six in a 24-hour period with a 15-minute rest for every hour worked. (4) The animal pulling a carriage shall not move at a speed faster than a slow trot. (5) No animal shall work with equipment causing an impairment of vision, other than normal blinders. (6) No animal shall be subject to any conditions which will impair the good health and physical condition of the animal. (b) The animal control unit may order the temporary suspension of the operation of any animal-drawn vehicle upon a determination that special circumstances exist which jeopardize the safety of the animal, such as bad weather or other environmental problems. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-222, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-202. - Equipment and facilities. Equipment and facilities with respect to animal-drawn vehicles must meet the following minimum standards: (1) The harness and bit shall be of standard construction and appropriate for the animal. It shall be properly fitted, padded and maintained, and kept free of makeshift wire, sisal rope and chain. The harness must be oiled and cleaned so as to be soft at all times. (2) Carriages must be properly lubricated and wheels must spin freely. (3) No driver may whip any animal with more than a light touch by a light whip. (4) Adequate water shall be provided in the working area and stables at all times. (5) Drivers of animal-drawn vehicles shall maintain stands in a sanitary condition at all times. (6) Stalls and stables must comply with the following: a. Ceilings in the stalls and stables must be at least ten feet high from bedding and flooring. Bedding therein must be at least six inches deep and dry enough so as not to show wetness under the pressure of the animal's hoofs. Sharp surfaces shall not be permitted in any area or building where they may come in contact with the animals. b. Roofs must be kept free of leaks. c. Each animal must have a stall large enough for the animal to turn around. d. Food must be kept free of contamination. e. Animal areas must be treated to exterminate and repel insects. f. Ventilation must be provided in hot weather. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-223, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-203. - Inspections. The animal control unit shall be permitted to inspect all animals, carriages, stalls and stables at any reasonable time to ensure compliance with all provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-224, 6-13-2006) Secs. 8-204—8-229. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - IMPOUNDMENT AND ADOPTION
Sec. 8-230. - Impoundment authorized. (a) Any animal at-large or otherwise in violation of the provisions of this chapter may be impounded in the animal shelter or a designated location in a humane manner. The animal must be claimed by the owner or his representative within three days. (b) The following animals may be impounded, but are not limited solely to: (1) Animals running at-large; (2) Animals, the ownership of which is unknown; (3) Vicious dogs; (4) Female dogs/cats in heat and off the premises of their owners; (5) Dogs/cats which have bitten a person or animal or which had been bitten by a dog or animal suspected of having rabies; (6) Dogs/cats not vaccinated for rabies within the preceding 12 months; (7) Dogs/cats which have strayed from the premises of their owners; (8) Dogs/cats suspected of having rabies; (9) Unconfined dogs/cats in quarantine areas. (c) If an animal so impounded has not been reclaimed by its owner or his representative within three days in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, such animal shall become the absolute property of the animal control unit, which may convey ownership of such animal to any responsible person on such conditions as the animal control unit may prescribe or the animal control unit may humanely destroy such animal. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-246, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-231. - Entry onto private property. An animal control officer may follow an animal that has been seen by that officer running at-large onto private property to capture and impound that animal. No injunction, action or claim for damages may be brought against the animal control unit, its officers, agents or employees or any law enforcement officer with respect to action herein contemplated. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-247, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-232. - Notice to owner. The animal control unit shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner of any animal impounded in the animal shelter that the animal has in fact been impounded, of the manner by which the animal may be reclaimed, that the animal shall become the property of the animal control unit and be adopted out, and that the animal may be destroyed. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-248, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-233. - Notice of proposed destruction. Following impoundment of an animal found at-large, which animal has on it its owner's address, and prior to its destruction, the animal control unit shall give the owner five days' notice of the proposed destruction by certified letter, return receipt requested. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-249, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-234. - Holding animals due to quarantine or evidence of criminal prosecution. Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, the animal control unit may refuse to release any animal impounded in the animal shelter for rabies or contagious disease quarantine or for the use as evidence of criminal prosecution for such time period as the animal control unit may determine. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-250, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-235. - Destruction of animals due to disease, overcrowding, or likelihood of danger or injury to humans or other animals. Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, the animal control unit may humanely destroy any animal impounded in the animal shelter when the animal control unit reasonably believes that destruction of the animal is necessary to prevent disease or injury to the animals or to humans, due to overcrowding in the animal shelter, the presence or threatened presence of contagious disease, the likelihood of danger or injury to humans or animals, or any other condition. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-251, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-236. - Destruction of injured or diseased animals. Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, the animal control unit may humanely destroy any animal impounded in the animal shelter when the animal control unit reasonably believes the animal has sustained an injury or disease which will likely result in maiming, prolonged and/or severe suffering or death. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-252, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-237. - Reclaiming impounded animals. (a) The owner of an animal impounded in the animal shelter may claim the animal, upon presenting evidence satisfactory to the animal control unit of compliance with all provisions of this chapter and upon payment of fees and charges as provided in this section, such fees and charges shall not be in lieu of any fine or penalty otherwise provided by law. (b) Fees for reclaiming impounded animals shall be in the amount established by the city and amendable by resolution. (c) The owner of an animal impounded in the animal shelter shall be liable for the foregoing fees and charges notwithstanding the destruction or adoption of the animal. (d) Should the city enter into an intergovernmental agreement with another entity to provide services for impoundment and seizure of animals, and the fee structure of an entity providing such services to the city be different from that set out herein, the fees charged by that entity for the reclamation of impounded animals shall be controlling over the above. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-253, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-238. - Adoption. The animal control unit may convey ownership, permit adoption, of any animal which has become the property of the animal control unit, except dogs which have been designated as dangerous and potentially dangerous, to a responsible person subject to such conditions as may be prescribed by the animal control unit, including, but without limitation, the following: (1) Payment of an adoption fee and any vaccination, licensing or veterinary costs, which fees and costs shall be in the amount established by the city and amendable by resolution. (2) Evidence satisfactory to the animal control unit that the animal has been, or will be, examined by a veterinarian and required vaccinations, tests and permits be administered. Should the fee structure of an entity providing such services to the city be different from that set out herein, the fees charged by that entity shall be controlling over the above. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-254, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-239. - Records required to be kept. It shall be the duty of the animal control department to keep, or cause to be kept, accurate and detailed records of the impoundment and disposition of all animals coming into its custody. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-255, 6-13-2006) Secs. 8-240—8-256. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - QUARANTINE

No. 2006-06, § 14-278, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-260. - Notice to be given by signs on affected areas. Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Sterilization of dogs and cats in shelters, O.C.G.A. § 4-14-1 et seq.
Sec. 8-284. - Purpose. The mayor and council find that the breeding of dogs and cats acquired by the public from animal control shelters and private animal shelters and humane societies results in the birth of hundreds of animals who become strays, suffer privation and death, constitute a public nuisance and health hazard, and ultimately are impounded and destroyed at great public expense. It is therefore declared to be the policy of the city that preventing the breeding of dogs and cats acquired from such shelters and humane societies be encouraged. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-300, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-285. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Animal shelter means any facility operated by or under contract for the state, county or a municipality for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned, or unwanted dogs, cats, and other animals; any veterinary hospital or clinic operated by a veterinarian or veterinarians which operates for such purpose in addition to its customary purposes; and any facility operated, owned, or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society, or other nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing for and promoting the welfare, protection, and humane treatment of animals. Humane society means any unincorporated nonprofit organization existing for the purpose of prevention of cruelty to animals. Public or private animal refuge means harborers of unwanted animals of any breed, including crossbreeds, who provide food, shelter, and confinement for a group of dogs, a group of cats, or a combination of dogs and cats. Sexually mature animal means any dog or cat that has reached the age of 180 days or six months or more. Sterilization means the surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. Sterilization bond means a bond, posted and paid for at the time of adoption, to ensure compliance with the provisions of section 8-286 by the person adopting any dog, cat, or other animal. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-301, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-286. - Regulations. (a) Any public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by the state, county or a municipality, humane society, or public or private animal refuge shall make provisions for the sterilization of all dogs or cats acquired from such shelter, agency, society, or refuge by: (1) Providing sterilization by a licensed veterinarian before relinquishing custody of the animal. (2) Entering into a written agreement with the person acquiring such animal guaranteeing that sterilization will be performed by a licensed veterinarian within 30 days after acquisition of such animal in the case of an adult animal or within 30 days of the sexual maturity of the animal in the case of an immature animal; provided, however, that the requirements of this section shall not apply to any privately-owned animal which any shelter, agency, society, or refuge may have in its possession for any reason, and the owner of such animal claims or presents evidence that such animal is the property of such person. (b) Fee and cost responsibility. (1) All costs of sterilization pursuant to this section shall be the responsibility of the person acquiring such animal and, if performed prior to acquisition, may be included in any fees charged by the shelter, agency, society, or refuge for such animal. (2) A sterilization bond shall be paid by the adopting person at the time of adoption. The amount of the sterilization bond shall be determined by the chief, county police department, or his designee; it shall not exceed the amount of the highest cost of sterilization charged by veterinarians participating in the sterilization bond program. (3) The sterilization bond is redeemed by the licensed veterinarian who performs the sterilization and completes the written statement attesting the same, who should be a licensed veterinarian who has agreed previously to participate in the sterilization bond program. (4) The adopting person may redeem the sterilization bond upon presentation of satisfactory proof of sterilization, in a manner acceptable to the county animal control unit commander. The remaining cost of sterilization, if any, shall be the sole responsibility of the adopting person. (5) The sterilization bond will have a fixed expiration date, determined by the due date of the sterilization; however, such expiration date and due date may be extended in accordance with the provisions of section 8-286 and subsection (i) of this section. Upon the expiration of the sterilization bond, the sterilization bond shall be forfeited to the county animal control unit. (c) Any person acquiring an animal from a public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by the state, county or a municipality, humane society, or public or private animal refuge, which animal is not sterile at the time of acquisition, shall submit to the animal shelter, animal control agency, humane society, or public or private animal refuge a signed statement from the licensed veterinarian performing the sterilization required by this section within seven days after such sterilization attesting that such sterilization has been performed. (d) Every public or private animal shelter, animal control agency operated by the state, county or a municipality, humane society, or public or private animal refuge selling or offering for sale or exchange any dog or cat shall maintain and furnish to any person acquiring an animal from such shelter, agency, society, or refuge a current list of veterinarians licensed in this state who have notified the shelter, agency, society, or refuge that they are willing to perform sterilizations and the cost for such procedures. (e) In the event of the death of an adopted cat or dog before the due date of the sterilization, the adopting person shall establish the death of said cat or dog: (1) By filing with the city animal control unit an affidavit attesting to the fact the animal has died; or (2) By leaving the body of the dog or cat with personnel of the county animal control unit for verification of death; or (3) By providing to personnel of the county animal control unit a statement from a licensed veterinarian attesting to the death of the animal. The proof of death of the cat or dog must be provided to the animal control unit before the due date of sterilization. If the adopting person does not provide such proof within the period specified, he may be charged for failure to sterilize under this section. (f) In the event that the adopted dog or cat is stolen, the adopting person shall file a police report with the appropriate jurisdiction, stating the circumstances of theft and a description of the animal in as much detail as possible. The police report shall be presented to animal control before the due date of the sterilization to relieve the adopting person of the sterilization requirement. (g) In the event that the adopted dog or cat runs away, or is lost or is given away by the adopting person, the adopting person shall not be relieved from the sterilization requirement. However, upon disposition of a case where this subsection is applicable, the adopting person shall be relieved of future responsibility as to that dog or cat. (h) If the dog or cat is unable to be sterilized due to a medical condition or other reason which would affect the dog's or cat's well-being, the adopting person shall provide a written statement from a licensed veterinarian attesting to the condition preventing the animal's sterilization. If such written statement is not in the possession of the animal control unit on or before the due date for sterilization, it shall constitute the offense of failure to sterilize against the adopting person. (i) It shall be the sole responsibility of the adopting person to provide proof of sterilization, on or before the due date of sterilization, to the county animal control unit. In the event of a dispute as to the due date of sterilization, a licensed veterinarian shall determine the due date of sterilization; said determination shall be in writing and in the possession of the animal control unit on or before the previous due date of sterilization. If such proof or such determination is not in the possession of the county animal control unit on or before the due date for sterilization, it shall constitute the offense of failure to sterilize against the adopting person. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-302, 6-13-2006) Sec. 8-287. - Penalty for violation. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in section 1-11. Each and every violation of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. No. 2006-06, § 14-303, 6-13-2006)

div.head: Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Citations. The building inspector or designee is authorized to issue citations for violations of this chapter. Sec. 10-2. - Emergency inspections. (a) Generally. Upon having credible, detailed information that conditions in any dwelling or other building create an imminent danger to the health, safety, or welfare of property of persons in the vicinity, and having identified with reasonable certainty that such conditions are in violation of state or local building codes and laws, the code enforcement officer, fire inspector and/or building inspector may report the same to the city police, specifying the bases and information received. Upon receiving such information, the city police may: (1) Exercise the authority granted to them by state law in to enter the premises in emergency situations; (2) Notify utility service providers of an imminent danger if it potentially involves utility services; (3) Request entry into the building or dwelling from a person authorized to grant such permission, in order to identify the cause or origin of the hazardous situation and suggest action to the owner or take such action as is immediately necessary to protect the lives and/or property of others. In the event entry is refused, the city police may resort to the authority described in subsection (a)(1) of this section in determining if a warrantless entry is necessary and authorized by law, or if a warrant should be sought from a court of proper jurisdiction. (b) Limitation on police authority. This section shall not be construed to limit or diminish the authority of law enforcement officers to enter any location when otherwise authorized to by law. (Ord. No. 2009-15, § 1(18-25), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-3. - Technical and building codes adopted, incorporated by reference. The most recent edition of the following technical and building codes are hereby adopted by the city by reference: (1) International Code Council (hereinafter "ICC") — International Building Code. (2) National Fire Protection Association (hereinafter "NFPA") — National Electrical Code. (3) ICC — International Fuel Gas Code. (4) ICC — International Mechanical Code. (5) ICC — International Plumbing Code. (6) ICC — International Residential Code for One- and Two- Family Dwellings. (7) ICC — International Energy Conservation Code. (8) ICC — International Fire Code. (9) NFPA — Life Safety Code. (Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 3-17-2014) State Law reference— State building codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-20-20 et seq. Secs. 10-4—10-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY; TERMINATION OF UTILITY SERVICE
Sec. 10-23. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building means any structure requiring a certificate of occupancy prior to being lawfully occupied. Certificate of occupancy means the document issued by the city signifying that all inspections pursuant to a building permit have been completed, that authorizes the initiation of utility service and/or authorizes the occupancy of the structure for the purposes it was built. Hazardous condition means any condition or combination of conditions that pose a threat or danger to the health, safety, welfare of the occupants of a building, visitors to the building, or property surrounding the subject building. Hearing officer means the judge of the municipal court acting as a hearing officer for hearings as set out in this article. Re-occupancy inspection means an inspection by the city building inspector prior to the re-connection of utility service after a building has been determined to be vacant. Revoke, and forms of that term, means the revocation of the authority to occupy the structure, the authority for a utility provider to provide service to the structure, and shall constitute the revocation of the certificate of occupancy as if it were never issued at all. Suspend, and forms of that term, means the temporary suspension of the certificate of occupancy for a building and the suspension of the authorization of a utility service provider to provide service. Utility service provider means any authority, corporation, partnership, or other entity providing electricity; water, natural, fuel oil or liquefied gas to a building. Vacancy suspension means a temporary suspension of a certificate of occupancy of a building based solely upon the building being vacant for more than 30 days. Vacant, and forms of that term, means and apply to a building that has not been occupied for the purpose for which it was built for more than 30 days next preceding the initiation of an action by the city. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 2(18-601), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-24. - Suspension of certificate of occupancy. (a) Notice of suspension. Upon the determination by the fire marshal, code enforcement officer, or building inspector that a hazardous condition exists that poses a threat to the safety or property of others, said official may provide a notice to the owner of said property and the occupant of the property that the city intends to seek the suspension of any existing certificate of occupancy on said property. The notice shall identify with specificity the conditions upon which the city relies in seeking such suspension, the date, time and place of a hearing on the issue, and any citations to which the city claims have been violated. The notices shall be mailed certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of the property as listed on the county tax assessor's Internet website, the occupant of the property at the property's address and posted prominently on the property. All mailing will request forwarding if an address change is filed. If the property occupant is not known, notice shall be mailed to the address of the property. (b) Hearing. A hearing to determine the existence of a hazardous condition such as would pose a threat to the safety or property of others shall be held before the hearing officer, not less than 15 days but not more than 30 days after the notices described in subsection (a) of this section are mailed or served personally. The burden shall be upon the city to prove the existence of such hazardous conditions as are set forth in the notice by a preponderance of the evidence. The city may be represented by the city attorney. The owner may be represented by counsel at his expense. Upon a finding that hazardous conditions exists, the hearing officer may: (1) Order the suspension be extended up to 60 days upon a showing that the hazardous conditions will be eliminated within that time, or (2) Order the certificate of occupancy on the property be revoked, effective not less than ten days nor more than 30 days from the date of the order. (c) Appeal. An appeal may be taken from the findings of the hearing officer and shall be heard by the mayor and council. A notice of appeal shall be filed not more than ten days from the entry of the order and shall be heard within 20 days of the filing of said appeal. The entry of an appeal shall not act as a supersedeas unless the owner posts a bond in a sufficient amount as determined by the hearing officer. Said bond shall be posted with the city clerk and held until the final resolution of the case. (d) Vacancy suspension issued. Upon the building inspector receiving credible information and forming a reasonable belief that a building is vacant as defined in this article, the building inspector shall issue a vacancy suspension for the building. The building inspector shall cause a notice to be sent to the owner of the building, as appearing on the county tax assessor's Internet website and the utility service providers for fuel oil, natural or propane gas, and electricity, if applicable, and post a notice on the building in a prominent place. Said service to the owner shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 3(18-602), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-25. - Revocation of certificates of occupancy. (a) Revocation. A certificate of occupancy may be revoked: (1) By the order of the hearing officer as set out in this article; or (2) After the certificate of occupancy has been suspended after the order of the hearing officer as set out in this article for 90 days or more without the owner of the building having required permits and inspections for remediation of hazardous conditions on the property. (b) Effect of revocation. Any building for which the certificate of occupancy has been revoked must meet all requirements for a certificate of occupancy in force at the time of application for a subsequent building permit. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 4(18-603), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-26. - Utility service to vacant homes; inspections. (a) Utility service to vacant homes. No utility service provider may provide electricity, natural gas, propane gas or fuel oil to a building that is vacant as defined in this article without the owner first having obtained an inspection as set out in this article. (b) Notification of utility service providers. Upon determination by the code enforcement officer that a building is vacant as described in this article, the city shall notify any utility service provider that has provided electricity, natural or propane gas, or fuel oil to the building that an inspection is required as set out in this article prior to providing further utility service to the building. (c) Inspection. After the determination that a building is vacant, prior to obtaining utility service, an owner or occupant must first obtain a re-occupancy inspection as described in this article. (d) Re-occupancy inspection. The inspection required prior to a utility service provider providing service to a vacant building shall be conducted by the city building inspector and will determine if the building is safe for connection to natural or propane gas service, the provision of fuel oil, and connection to electric service. The building inspector shall provide to the owner, occupant and utility service provider the results of the inspection and/or any defects discovered. The fee for such inspection shall be a maximum amount as established by the city and amendable by resolution. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 6(18-611), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-27. - Non-exclusivity of remedies. This article is not intended to limit the remedies and actions available to the city in addressing buildings, locations and property presenting conditions hazardous or detrimental to the health, safety, welfare and property values of the city or its citizens and visitors. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 8(18-621), 12-14-2009) Sec. 10-28. - Penalties. (a) It shall be a violation of this Code for a person corporation, partnership, association or entity of any type to occupy any building for which the certificate of occupancy has been suspended or revoked. (b) It shall be a violation of this Code for a person, corporation, partnership, association or entity of any type to connect or provide natural gas, propane gas, fuel oil or electric utility service to a building for which the certificate of occupancy has been suspended or revoked. (c) Punishment for a violation of this section shall be punished as set out in section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2009-14, § 9(18-622), 12-14-2009) Secs. 10-29—10-65. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— State building codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-20-20 et seq.
Sec. 10-66. - Amendments, modifications and exceptions. The building code adopted by this chapter is hereby amended, altered, and changed in the following respects: 105. Section 105, board of adjustment and appeals, is hereby amended to read as follows: 105.1. Board members and procedures. 105.1.1. Appointment. There is hereby established a board of adjustment and appeals, which shall consist of five members. Four members shall be from the building or contracting industry including at least one member from the residential building industry and one member from the commercial/industrial industry. The fifth member of the board shall be a state-registered architect or engineer. 105.1.2. Terms of office. The board members shall be appointed by the mayor and council to serve initial terms from one to three years. Two members shall serve for an initial term of one year; two members shall serve for an initial term of two years; and one member shall serve for an initial term of three years. Thereafter, members shall be appointed for terms of three years. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term in the manner in which original appointments are required to be made. Continued absence of any member from regular meetings of the board shall, at the discretion of the mayor and council, render any such member liable for immediate removal from office. 105.1.3. Quorum. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum. In varying the application of any provisions of the building or fire codes, or in modifying an order of the building inspector, or fire marshal of the county, affirmative votes of the majority present, but not less than three affirmative votes, shall be required. A board member shall not act in a case in which he has a personal interest. 105.1.4. Secretary, records. The building inspector shall act as secretary to the board of adjustments and appeals. The secretary shall make a detailed record of all the board's proceedings, which shall include providing the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of a member, and any failure of a member to vote. 105.1.5. Procedure. The board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this article or any other code adopted by the county. The board shall meet at regular intervals, to be determined by the chairperson. In any event, the board shall meet within ten days after notice of appeal has been received. Every decision shall be promptly filed in writing in the office of the building inspector and fire marshal and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the building inspector and fire marshal for two weeks after filing. 105.2. Appeals. 105.2.1. General. Whenever the building inspector or fire marshal of the county shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of construction proposed to be followed or materials to be used in the installation or alteration of a building or structure, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the building or fire codes do not apply, or that any equally good or more desirable form of installation can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the building or fire codes or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or incorrectly interpreted, the owner of such building or structure, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the building inspector or fire marshal to the board of adjustments and appeals. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within 30 days after the decision is rendered by the building inspector or fire marshal. 105.2.2. Unsafe or dangerous buildings. In case of a building or structure which, in the opinion of the building inspector or fire marshal, is unsafe or dangerous, the building inspector or fire marshal may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. 105.3. Decisions. 105.3.1. Variances. The board of adjustments and appeals, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of the building or fire codes to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of the codes or public interest, or when, in its opinion, the interpretation of the building inspector or fire marshal should be modified or reversed. 105.3.2. Action. The board of adjustment and appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Each decision of the board shall also include the reasons for the decision. If a decision of the board reverses or modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the building inspector or fire marshal or varies the application of any provision of the building or fire codes, the building inspector or fire marshal shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. 105.3.3. Decisions are final. Every decision of the board of adjustments and appeals shall be final; subject, however, to such remedy as any aggrieved party has at law or in equity. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 5(18-27), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-67. - Buildings, commercial and industrial. (a) Materials. (1) On all major arterial and collector streets, as defined in the land use plan of the city, and all other streets where buildings or parts thereof are visible from these major arterial and collector streets, all exposed exterior wall sidings shall be composed of the following maximum and minimum percentages of materials in each classification. The percentages apply to the siding on each exposed exterior wall of each building visible from the street on which such building is located:
(2) A description of each material type in the table above is as follows: a. Type A material: To consist of face brick, granite, stone, marble, terrazzo, architecturally-treated reinforced concrete slabs either fluted or with exposed aggregate, insulated window wall panels or stainless steel, porcelain-treated steel, anodized or other permanently finished aluminum. b. Type B material: To consist of metal panels with a baked-on enamel or acrylic finish (which must be expected to retain its appearance without substantial maintenance for a period of ten years), stucco, Dryvit, concrete block with either sculptured treatment or stack bond with sculptured treatment, or split-faced decorative block. c. Type C material: To consist of asbestos board, plain reinforced concrete slabs, concrete block with either sculptured treatment or stacked bond and raked joints. d. Type D material: To consist of corrugated steel and aluminum without the finish prescribed in subsection (a)(2)b of this section, plain concrete block, redwood or other decorative wood, Masonite, or particle board. (3) Materials not listed may be presented to the building inspector for classification. (b) Buildings having walls over 20 feet high may be given special material percentages by the building inspector. (c) Where buildings located on streets other than major arterials and collectors are visible from the major arterial and collector streets, the building inspector may, at his discretion, approve alternative methods of obscuring the view of such buildings from the major arterial and collector streets. These methods may include, but are not limited to, fencing, planted landscape buffer screens, berms, etc. (d) The mayor and council, or its designee, may grant a variance of up to 50 percent of the requirements of this section when, in the opinion of the mayor and council, or its designee, the intent of this section will better be served by a relaxation of the requirements contained therein. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 5(18-28), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-68. - Fee schedule. (a) Adopted. No building permit shall be valid until the required fees have been paid. The schedule of permit fees is as established by the city and amendable by resolution. (b) Failure to obtain a permit. If any person commences any work on a building or structure before obtaining the necessary permit from the city, he may be subject to the penalties described herein: (1) Where work is commenced before a permit is obtained, the permit fee shall double in price. (2) On final inspection, any item not previously listed on the permit and fees paid will be charged at double the listed fees. (3) Citation to be adjudicated in the city municipal court. (Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1(18-29), 3-20-2017) Sec. 10-69. - Single-family residential dwelling construction standards. (a) Gutters. Full length gutters and downspouts shall be required on single-family attached or detached dwellings. The building inspector shall be empowered to waive this requirement if other water runoff control is provided, and the Code would be better served thereby. (b) Exterior siding. Single-family attached or detached dwelling units utilizing vinyl siding or stucco siding must utilize at the minimum 7/16 OSB sheathing under vinyl or stucco on the first floor of the structure. Stucco must be Portland cement based stucco, installed over wire lathe with 15-pound felt. Porous fillers, such as expanded plastic or foam may not be added to exterior stucco. (c) Flashing. Flashing is required over windows and doors. Self-flashing windows and doors shall not require additional flashing. Window frames and door frames must be sealed on all sides against water leakage, utilizing any appropriate method of construction. (d) Garages. All single-family attached or detached dwellings shall have attached or detached, two-car garages, enclosed on at least three sides, and be architecturally consistent with the home. In the RS-110, single-family zoning district, homes shall have a minimum of a one-car garage, provided that the garage does not open to the street. In any subdivision built to meet the RS-65 development requirements, each home shall have a minimum of a one-car garage. In the RS-180, RS-180A, RS-300, ER, and A, single-family zoning districts at least 33 percent of the homes built in any subdivision platted after August 19, 1999 shall have garages that do not face the street. (e) Roof pitch. Each single-family dwelling shall have a minimum of 5:12 slope for roof pitch. Single-family homes built in the RS-110, RS-65, or RM zoning districts shall have at least one change in roof line. Single-family homes built in the RS-180, RS-180A, RS-300, ER, and A zoning districts must have at least two changes in roof line. (f) Facade requirements. In all single-family zoning districts, or new single-family developments, at least 33 percent of the homes built in any subdivision platted after August 19, 1999 shall have front facades fully constructed of brick, stone, or stucco. This requirement shall not prohibit the construction of wall facades using windows, doors, or other substantial architectural features. An additional 33 percent of homes built in any subdivision platted after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived must have front facades constructed with architectural accents made of brick, stone, or stucco. In any subdivision constructed to meet the RS-65 zoning district development restrictions, homes built within three feet of the property line must be fire-rated, irrespective of the distance to the adjacent house. No exterior wall may be sided with vinyl if that wall is within three feet of the property line. The building inspector shall issue building permits to ensure that there is an even distribution of building facade types throughout the subdivision's construction. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 5(18-30), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-70. - Multifamily residential dwelling construction standards. (a) Applicability. This section shall apply to all multifamily apartments, duplex, townhouse, and condominium developments built in the RM, RMTH, and the RG-75 residential zoning districts. Single-family homes constructed in any residential zoning district shall be built to the construction standards as required in this section, single-family residential dwelling construction standards. (b) Gutters. Full length gutters and downspouts shall be required on all buildings in any development. The building inspector shall be empowered to waive this requirement if other water runoff control is provided, and the Code would be better served thereby. (c) Exterior siding. All buildings utilizing vinyl siding or stucco siding must have 7/16 OSB sheathing under the vinyl or stucco on all floors of the structure. Stucco must be Portland cement based stucco, installed over wire lathe with ten-pound felt. Porous fillers, such as expanded plastic or foam may not be added to exterior stucco. (d) Foundation. Each building foundation should have a concrete perimeter footing and stem wall with continuous foundations under interior load-bearing walls. (e) Flashing. Flashing is required over windows and doors. Self-flashing windows and doors shall not require additional flashing. Window frames and door frames must be sealed on all sides against water leakage, utilizing any appropriate method of construction. (f) Roof pitch. Each multifamily building shall have a minimum of 5:12 slope for roof pitch. All multifamily buildings shall have no less than three substantial changes in roof line. (g) Interior amenities. Each dwelling unit shall have hookups for washers and dryers. All sheetrock shall be glued and screwed utilizing appropriate building materials. There shall be sound insulation installed in all walls and floors between dwelling units. (h) Facade requirements. Fifty percent of each building wall shall be constructed with either brick, stone, or stucco. No building wall shall have more than 40 feet of one straight-line contiguous wall facade. The minimum variation for each change in wall depth shall be 16 inches. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 5(18-31), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-71. - Penalties for violation. Any person in violation of this article shall, if convicted, be punished in accordance with section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 5(18-32), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-72. - Central heat required. In all habitable dwellings, central heating shall be required. The heating units shall be of a capacity that the habitable portions of the dwelling shall be capable of maintaining a temperature of at least 63 degrees Fahrenheit three feet above the flooring of the structure. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless there is utility service for heating ready for connection to the dwelling. (Ord. No. 2009-13, § 1(18-33), 12-14-2009) Secs. 10-73—10-108. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— State building codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-20-20 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 10-109. - Applicability. This article shall govern and regulate electricians, electrical installers, electrical inspectors, and other persons or legal entities involved with electrical services in the city. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 9(18-51), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-110. - Supplementary rules and regulations. (a) The building inspector shall promulgate rules relating to electrical conductors and equipment as prescribed in this article and consistent therewith, it being the intent of this requirement that the standards of federal and state bureaus, national technical organizations or fire underwriters, as the same may be amended from time to time, shall serve as a guide in fixing the minimum rules of practice under this Code. (b) For the purpose of securing for the public the benefits of new developments and yet ensuring public safety, the building inspector shall make or cause to be made investigations, or may accept duly authenticated reports from recognized sources, of new materials, appliances, equipment or systems intended for use in the city which are not provided for in this article, and shall promulgate rules setting forth the conditions under which such materials, appliances, equipment or systems may be used. (c) No rule of the building inspector shall become effective until four weeks after notice of intention to enforce it shall have been given all registered individuals. Such rule must be drawn in its proposed form and open to public inspection at the time the notice to enforce is published. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 9(18-52), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-111. - Penalty for chapter violation. Any person violating the provisions of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 9(18-54), 12-17-2001) Secs. 10-112—10-135. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 10-136. - General authority of building inspector. The building inspector shall have general charge of administration only over all electrical work done in the city. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 12(18-66), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-137. - Building inspector's duties. The building inspector shall receive applications for permits required by this article, issue such permits, and furnish certification that completed electrical work is in accordance with this article. He shall examine plans for which permits are to be issued and shall make necessary inspections to see that the provisions of law are complied with so that electrical installations are safely performed. He shall enforce all laws relating to the installation and maintenance of electricity in buildings and structures except as may be otherwise provided for in other applicable ordinances. It shall be his duty to make inspections of electrical installations already installed upon complaint of unsafe conditions. He is hereby empowered to secure compliance with the law and to require the removal of illegal or unsafe conditions within five days, or 24 hours in case of emergency, after written notice has been given. He shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary. When the term "chief electrical inspector" is used in this article, it shall mean the chief electrical inspector or his deputized representatives. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 12(18-67), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-138. - Right of entry for inspection purposes. Inspections required under the provisions of this article shall be made by the building inspector or his duly authorized representatives. Upon presentation of proper credentials, he may enter at reasonable times any building, structure or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by this article. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 12(18-69), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-139. - Enforcement powers. (a) Orders to correct violations. The building inspector shall have authority, when he is satisfied that any electrical wiring, equipment or appliance is in violation of the provisions or requirements of this chapter or in violation of the detailed statement or plan submitted and approved, to issue a written order upon the person responsible therefor, directing discontinuance of such illegal action and the remedying of the condition that is in violation. In case such notice is not promptly complied with, the building inspector shall request the proper prosecuting authority to institute an appropriate action at law or in equity to restrain, correct or remove such violation. (b) Stopping work. Whenever, in the opinion of the building inspector or his authorized representatives, by reason of defective or illegal work in violation of a provision or requirement of this article, the continuance of an electrical operation is contrary to public welfare, he shall order, in writing, all further electrical work to be stopped and may require suspension of all electrical work until the condition in violation has been corrected. (c) Disconnecting current. The building inspector shall have authority, after due notice, to cut off current to any electric wiring, equipment or appliance which, in his opinion, is unsafe to life or property, and to enforce discontinuance of the same until the electric wiring, equipment or appliance is made safe in conformance with this article. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 12(18-70), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-140. - Records of permits, inspections, etc. (a) The building inspector shall keep comprehensive records of applications, of permits issued, of inspections made, of reports rendered, and of notices or orders issued. He shall retain on file copies of required plans and all documents relating to equipment, appliances or systems for which a permit has been issued for a period of not less than two years after final inspection. (b) All such records shall be open to public inspection for good and sufficient reasons at office hours observed by the city, but shall not be removed from the office of the building inspector. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 12(18-71), 12-17-2001) Secs. 10-141—10-163. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS
Sec. 10-164. - When permit required. It shall be unlawful to construct, install, alter or repair or to commence the construction, installation, alteration or repair of any electrical system, appliance or equipment without first filing with the building inspector an application in writing, obtaining a permit, and paying all fees. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-81), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-165. - Time limit for obtaining permit. An electrical permit shall be secured from the electrical division not less than four hours before any electrical work is started. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-82), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-166. - Application for permit. (a) Application for a permit for electrical work shall be made on forms prepared and provided by the electrical division and shall be filled out in accordance with the instructions on such application forms. Electrical permits shall be issued only to holders of a valid license in keeping with the National Electrical Code, as adopted and amended by the city, which shall be exhibited when a permit is requested, and except as otherwise provided in such electrical code. (b) Such application shall describe briefly the proposed work and shall give such additional information as may be required by the building inspector for an intelligent understanding of the proposed work. Such application shall be accompanied by plans and specifications containing the seal and signature of a registered, professional electrical engineer licensed by the state, except when it is determined by the building inspector that the permit form provides sufficient information. When the building inspector determines it to be appropriate, a single line diagram shall be accepted, indicating service equipment, distribution panels and feeders. Such diagram shall show the short-circuit current ratings for all over-current protective devices and, when required, shall indicate a short-circuit study of the distribution system. Such submittal shall indicate the voltage, phase, number of conductors, and the calculated maximum RMS symmetrical amperes available at the supply terminals of the service equipment. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-83), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-167. - Payment of permit fees required. The fee schedule is adopted as provided in section 10-206. Such fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of a permit. No electrical permit shall be valid until the fees described in such schedule have been paid to the city. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-84), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-168. - Conditions, limitations of permit. (a) All work performed under a permit issued under this article shall conform to the approved application and plans and to all codes or resolutions governing the work or equipment for which the permit is issued, and it shall be performed by an individual contractor, firm or corporation licensed as required by the city. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-86), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-170. - Revocation of permit. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-89), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-173. - Certificates of approval. When work is finished and approved, the building inspector shall issue a certificate of approval which shall authorize the current to be turned on. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-90), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-174. - Additions to authorized work. No. 2001-23, § 15(18-92), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-176. - Temporary service. (a) Temporary service may be installed, when proper forms have been submitted to the building inspector, for the following purposes: (1) To be used to supply power for the purpose of hoisting material used in buildings under construction or remodeling, and for the purpose of lighting such buildings or structures used in connection with the construction of such buildings. (a) The board of adjustments and appeals shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this article. (b) The building inspector shall act as secretary of the board of adjustments and appeals and shall make a detailed record of all its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons for its decisions, the vote of each member participating therein, the absence of a member, and any failure of a member to vote. (a) Whenever the building inspector shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of installation proposed to be followed or materials to be used in the electrical installation or when it is claimed the provisions of this article do not apply or that an equally good or more desirable form of electrical materials can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of this article or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the electrician, installer, or contractor, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal from the decision of the building inspector to the board of adjustments and appeals. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within 90 days after the decision is rendered by the building inspector. A fee in the amount established by the city and amendable by resolution shall accompany such notice of appeal. (b) In the case of a building or structure which, in the opinion of the building inspector, is unsafe or dangerous, the building inspector may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. Appeals hereunder shall be on forms provided by the building inspector. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 21(18-119), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-240. - Authority to vary, modify application. (a) The board of adjustments and appeals, when appealed to under this division and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of this article to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this article or public interest, or when, in its opinion, the interpretation of the building inspector should be modified or reversed. (b) A decision of the board of adjustments and appeals to vary the application of any provision of this article or to modify an order of the building inspector shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made, and the reasons therefor. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 21(18-120), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-241. - Decisions. (a) The board of adjustments and appeals shall, in every case of an appeal under this division, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Every decision of the board of adjustments and appeals shall be final, subject, however, to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. It shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in the office of the building inspector and shall be open to public inspection; a certified copy shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant, and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the building inspector for two weeks after filing. A copy of every decision so rendered shall be forwarded to the state building administrative board, an agency of the state, for review. (b) If a decision of the board of adjustments and appeals reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance of the building inspector or varies the application of any provision of this article, the building inspector shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. These reports shall go to the mayor and council. (b) It shall be the duty of the building inspector to make inspections of plumbing already in, upon complaint of its unsanitary conditions, and, upon notice to do so, the owner, agent or lessee of such property inspected shall make any changes required in such notice. Failure to make any such changes within five days after notice shall subject the owner, agent or lessee to a fine, as prescribed under state law. (c) It shall also be the duty of the building inspector to inspect all plumbing done in the city during the process of such work, as well as when it is completed; such inspections to be made from time to time and to be thorough and complete. (b) A decision of the board of adjustments and appeals to vary the application of any provision of this article or to modify an order of the building inspector shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made, and the reasons therefor. Sec. 10-863. - Application procedure; requirements. (a) Any person who desires to move a house or other building or buildings into, out of or through the city shall first make application to the building inspector for an escort permit, such application to be made at least two calendar days prior to the date of movement. (b) The applicant shall certify the routing of the movement, the date and time of the movement, the tonnage weight of the loaded vehicle or vehicles moving the building or buildings and the safety precautions to be utilized in the protection of personal and property rights of others during such movement. The building inspector may require additional information and/or safety precautions if, in his judgment, he does not believe the moving plans to be feasible or that the necessary safety precautions are being taken. If he does disapprove, he may require that a different routing and/or additional safety precautions be taken in order to protect the personal and property rights of individuals. (c) The applicant must, upon making application, give the width, length and height of the building to be moved. No routing will be approved for movement without assurance that the movement can be made without disturbing or damaging obstructions on the sides or above the route to be taken. If there are any road signs, mailboxes, overhead wiring, traffic lights, traffic signals, bridges or other obstacles on the route chosen, it shall be the duty of the applicant to ensure that the building or structure that is being moved shall clear all of these obstructions without damage. (d) Any person who desires to move a house or other building or buildings into, out of or through the city shall post with the building inspector a cash bond in the established by the city and amendable by resolution. Such bond shall be used to repair, replace or otherwise compensate the city or any citizens of the city damaged by the moving of a building or structure through the city. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the liability of any person to the amount of the bond. If, after 15 days from the receipt of a notice of claim for damages to the mover, the mover fails to respond, the building inspector may, at his discretion, use such cash bond to replace, repair or otherwise compensate the person for damages caused by the movement of the building or structure. The amount of cash bond expended shall be deposited by the mover within ten days' notice by the building inspector to maintain the cash bond at the required minimum amount. Failure to post the cash bond and maintain the cash bond at the required minimum amount shall result in the denial of any and all applications for moving of buildings or structures into or through the city. This bond shall be refunded upon written notification from the person that they are ceasing to do business in the city. (e) The applicant shall provide to the building inspector a certification from the county tax commissioner, and the taxing authorities of the city, that all ad valorem property taxes assessed against the building structure to be moved have been paid in full. In the event the current year's property taxes have not been assessed and/or billed, the applicant or property owner shall cause to be paid to the tax commissioner, and any taxing authority of an applicable municipality, an amount of property taxes assessed against the property to be moved equal to 80 percent of the amount assessed and/or paid on the property for the year immediately preceding the current year. Any payment caused to be made by the applicant or property owner in accordance with this section which is in excess of the finally determined tax liability shall be refunded to the applicant or property owner as the case may be. If the amount finally determined to be the tax liability for the property exceeds the amount paid under this section, the applicant or property owner shall be liable for the amount of the difference between the amount paid and the amount owed. In no event shall a moving permit be issued to an applicant to move any building structure through the city until the certification required by this section is tendered by the applicant. An applicant may have his business license suspended in the event any amounts provided to be paid under this section are due and owing to the county tax commissioner and/or taxing authorities of any applicable municipality. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-496), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-864. - Pre-moving inspection fee. If the building or structure is to be relocated to a site within the city, such building or structure must be inspected by the building inspector prior to its removal from the original site. The purpose of this inspection is to determine if such building or structure meets all applicable code standards of the city. If such building or structure cannot be modified so as to comply with all applicable codes of the city, such buildings or structure may not be moved into the city. The fee for this inspection fee shall be in the amount established by resolution and amendable by resolution. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-497), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-865. - Denial of permit where building is of excessive width. All applications for moving permits shall be checked by the building inspector as to routing, and no permit shall be granted where the width of the building exceeds 30 feet or exceeds the right-of-way width of the public road, street or thoroughfare. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-498), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-866. - Relocation moving permits to be approved only by the mayor and council; criteria; inspections. All applications for moving permits where the building being moved is to be relocated in the city shall be submitted to the mayor and council of the city by the building inspector prior to any permit being issued. The mayor and council, upon hearing an application, shall take into consideration all of the factors involved, including the relocation site, the buildings in the community where the relocation site is located, and all other matters pertinent to compatibility and feasibility of the proposed building's relocation, so as not to disturb the overall values of the community. Any building that is to be relocated in the city must have an inspection before it is moved, and the building inspector shall make his recommendation to the mayor and council as to whether or not it meets all of the standards of the city zoning laws, building codes, and other related subjects. If the mayor and council elects to award the relocation moving permit, once it is relocated it must be completely remodeled and meet final inspection of the building inspection department prior to occupancy and within 90 days from the date it is relocated. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-499), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-867. - Additional fees for relocation moving inspections. In addition to all other fees required by this article, including the escort permit fee and the pre-moving inspection fee referred to in section 10-864, an additional fee in the amount established and by the city and amendable by resolution shall be charged for the post-moving inspection which shall occur prior to the occupancy of such building or structure. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-500), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-868. - Prearrangement on clearance of utility lines prior to permit being issued. The applicant for the permit shall give satisfactory arrangements to the building inspection department as to the arrangements being made with the various utility companies for the clearance of utility lines along the entire route of the proposed movement. (Ord. No. 2001-23, § 91(18-501), 12-17-2001) Sec. 10-869. - Penalty for division violation. Any person who violates the provisions of this division shall be charged with a violation, and the mayor and council, after hearing the complaint and all of the evidence, if they find that in fact this division has been violated, may enter an order requiring compliance and, in addition, may refuse to grant any further permits to such person.
