Security shall be determined by the mayor and council with the advice and consent of the judge. The judge may adopt rules for the operation of the court relating to safety and security. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 3(30-3), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-33. - City solicitor; qualifications; appointment; duties; compensation; absence. There shall be created the position of city solicitor ("solicitor" hereinafter). The solicitor shall be responsible for the prosecution of all cases appearing before the court, consistent with the status of current law. The solicitor shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia at all times appearing before the court. The solicitor shall be appointed to one-year terms, each term beginning with the first council meeting of each calendar year, said appointment being made by the majority vote of the mayor and council. In the event a vacancy is created by resignation of the solicitor, the mayor and council shall be authorized to appoint a replacement for the remainder of the term of the solicitor so vacating the position. In the event of the disqualification of the solicitor from the prosecution of any case, the absence of the solicitor, or vacancy in that position, the city's attorney may prosecute in the court. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 4(30-4), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-34. - Indigent defense. The city shall provide legal representation to indigent defendants coming before the court. The court shall cause persons requesting indigent defense to certify, under oath, their financial status and shall authorize the employment of defense counsel in such cases. The mayor and council shall engage attorneys to represent said persons or authorize the same. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 5(30-5), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-35. - Probation services. The mayor and council, through resolution, shall designate an entity to provide probation supervision services to the court. Said entity will operate at the direction of the court, and shall forward all funds and reports of collections to the city clerk as demanded and all reports of compliance by clients to the court as ordered. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 6(30-6), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-36. - Clerk of municipal court. The clerk of the municipal court shall be appointed by the mayor and council and shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council, notwithstanding other law. The clerk shall perform all duties as established by law, including, but not limited to, the maintenance of dockets; collection of funds, distribution of fines, forfeitures, and other costs and fees as required by law; maintenance of all records as required by law, and other duties as required by law. Compensation of the clerk shall be established by the mayor and council. The clerk shall comply with all requirements for training and certification required by law, and any costs of said training shall be at the expense of the city. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 7(30-7), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-37. - Intergovernmental agreements for court services authorized. Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as to prohibit the mayor and council from entering into intergovernmental agreements for the provision of court services or services related to the operation of the municipal court. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 8(30-8), 4-10-2007) Secs. 26-38—26-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BONDS, SUPERSEDEAS BONDS AND RECOGNIZANCES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to provide for forfeiture of bonds of offenders, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-4.
Sec. 26-61. - Manner of forfeiture of bonds and recognizances. Bail, bonds, supersedeas bonds and similar obligations shall be forfeited in the municipal court in the manner as provided in this article. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-13), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-62. - Proceeding to forfeit upon non-appearance. Upon the failure to appear or comply with the conditions of a bond by any principal in any bond or recognizance given by or for the benefit of a person charged with or convicted of a violation of a city ordinance, or by a witness to appear and testify, the judge of the municipal court shall proceed to forfeit such bond or recognizance in the manner set out by law for courts in this state. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-14), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-63. - Scire facias to issue; appropriation of cash obligations. The court clerk shall issue or cause to be issued scire facias on all forfeited bonds, recognizances or other obligations, returnable to the next term of the court, coming before the court, against the principal and his sureties, which shall be served by the city at least five days before the return thereof; or, if the party resides out of the state or county, scire facias may be served by publication, as in cases of scire facias to revive judgments, and if said party resides in said county, outside of the corporate limits of the city, the same shall be served by the sheriff or his deputy. If, at such return term, no sufficient cause is shown to the contrary, judgment shall be entered up against such principal and sureties or such of them as have been served. Provided, however, if such bond or recognizance given is cash or its equivalent, upon failure of the defendant to appear at the court at the appointed time, judgment shall be entered up against such defendant, and the bond so given shall be forfeited. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-15), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-64. - Execution of judgments. Final judgments in all cases of forfeitures shall be enforced by execution issued or cause to be issued by the court clerk, bearing teste in the name of the presiding officer of the court, and shall be in favor of the city or its designee, and against the principal and his sureties on the bond, which execution shall be turned over to the police for levy and sale. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-16), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-65. - Re-arresting defendant and carrying out judgment. The principal or defendant then under conviction shall be re-arrested by the police under proper order of the court, and the sentence or judgment of conviction carried out. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-17), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-66. - Defense of illegality. Any defense to such execution shall be by affidavit of illegality, returnable to the next term of the superior court of the county, and the affidavit shall not be accepted by such officer unless the party offering the affidavit shall give bond with good security for the eventual condemnation money or make affidavit of his inability so to do. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-18), 4-10-2007) Sec. 26-67. - Bond amounts for various offenses. There shall be a schedule of cash bonds established by the judge of the municipal court that may be updated from time to time as he deems appropriate. Said schedule shall become effective as an order of the court and all bonds shall conform thereto. (Ord. No. 2007-03, § 10(30-19), 4-10-2007)

div.head: Chapter 28 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; abatement of nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 28-1. - Public nuisance in relation to dwelling, building, structure or property. (a) The mayor and council of the city, are authorized by O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-17 to exercise its police power to repair, close, or demolish certain defined dwellings, buildings, or structures in the manner provided in such sections when such property is in violation of the aforementioned code sections. (b) The mayor and council of the city find that there exist in the incorporated area of the city dwellings, buildings, or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business uses due to dilapidation and not in compliance with applicable codes; which have defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; which lack adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; which have other conditions in existence which render such dwellings, buildings, or structures unsafe or unsanitary, or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of such county; and which are vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes are being committed. (c) The definitions of terms in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8(1)—(12) are adopted as the definitions of those terms as used in this article. (d) It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the unincorporated areas of the county to construct and to maintain such dwelling, building, structure, or property in conformance with applicable codes in force within the jurisdiction, or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on the property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to construct or to maintain any dwelling, building, structure, or property in violation of such codes or ordinances. (e) The city or its designee is authorized to exercise the powers prescribed by this article, and, as such, come within the definition of the term "public officer" in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-8(10). (f) Charge, investigation, inspection, determination of unfit for habitation or use. (1) Whenever a request is filed with the public officer designated in subsection (e) of this section by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific dwelling, building, structure, or property. If the officer's investigation or inspection identifies that any dwelling, building, structure, or property is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the public officer may issue a complaint in rem against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists and shall cause a summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the interested parties for such dwelling, building, or structure. The complaint shall identify the subject real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; identify the interested parties; state with particularity the factual basis for the action; and contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance. The summons shall notify the interested parties that a hearing will be held before a court of competent jurisdiction as determined by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5, at a date and time certain and at a place within the city. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the proper court. The interested parties shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. (2) If, after such notice and hearing, the court determines that the dwelling, building, or structure in question is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes; is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing an order: a. If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes. b. If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property. c. For the purposes of this section, the court shall make its determination of reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be a factor in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a state appraiser classification as provided in O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 39A (O.C.G.A. § 43-39A-1 et seq.), qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violations in force in the jurisdiction. d. If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. Such abatement action shall commence within 270 days after the expiration of time specified in the order for abatement by the owner. Any time during which such action is prohibited by a court order issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13 or any other equitable relief granted by a court of competent jurisdiction shall not be counted toward the 270 days in which such abatement action must commence. The public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." e. If the public has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any monies received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of savaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The public officer and mayor and council are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. f. That the amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (3) Costs incurred; liens; enforcements. a. The lien provided for in subsection (f)(2)f of this section shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure, or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county where the real property is located and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(c). The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. b. Upon final determination of costs, fees, and expenses incurred in accordance with this chapter, the public officer responsible for enforcement actions in accordance with this chapter shall transmit to the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer a statement of the total amount due and secured by said lien, together with copies of all notices provided to interested parties. The statement of the public officer shall be transmitted within 90 days of completion of the repairs, demolition, or closure. It shall be the duty of the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer, who is responsible or whose duties include the collection of municipal taxes, to collect the amount of the lien using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem taxes, including specifically O.C.G.A. title 48, ch. 4 (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1 et seq.); provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. A county tax commissioner shall collect and enforce municipal liens imposed pursuant to this section in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359.1. The county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer shall remit the amount collected to the mayor and council of the city. c. Enforcement of liens may be initiated at any time following receipt by the county tax commissioner or municipal tax collector or city revenue officer of the final determination of costs. The unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties from and after the date of final determination of costs in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes. An enforcement proceeding pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 for delinquent ad valorem taxes may include all amounts due under this chapter. d. The redemption amount in any enforcement proceeding pursuant to this section shall be the full amount of the costs as finally determined in accordance with this section together with interest, penalties, and costs incurred by the mayor and council, county tax commissioner, municipal tax collector, or city revenue officer in the enforcement of such lien. Redemption of property from the lien may be made in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-80 and 48-4-81. (4) The mayor and city council may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building, or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (5) Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. (6) In addition to the procedures and remedies in this article, the mayor and councilmembers of the city may provide by ordinance that designated public officers may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and seek to enforce such citations in a court of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this section. (7) Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. (g) Complaints issued by the public officer pursuant to this article shall be served in the manner provided for in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(a)—(h). (Ord. of 10-15-2002, § 5(62-35); Ord. No. 2003-03, §§ 1—7, 5-19-2003) Secs. 28-2—28-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - QUALITY OF LIFE CODE
Sec. 28-21. - Purpose and definitions. (a) Purpose. The city council deems it in the best interest of the city and in furtherance of public safety and public welfare to enact certain requirements for the owners and occupants of real property which will require such property to be maintained in good repair, free from accumulation of rubbish and uncut vegetation, with pools and similar structures maintained in good repair or covered to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes, to provide for securing of vacant or abandoned structures and to control the parking of certain vehicles within residential districts of the city. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Code official means any city law enforcement officer, code enforcement officer of the police department, and any employee designated by the mayor. Notice means a notice of violation of these regulations by personal service or service by certified mail or first class mail to the last-known address of the party responsible for the violation. If the notice is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice. Regulations means the requirements set out in this article. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-201), 10-13-2008) Sec. 28-22. - Maintaining property and vacant structures, nuisance and abatement thereof. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in possession of any real property to utilize such real property for the outside storage of any ice box, refrigerator, stove or other appliance, furniture, clothing, machinery, equipment, glass, iron, paper, cordage, or other waste material, including building rubbish, trash, garbage or similar items, without a special permit therefor issued by the director of the department of community development. (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in possession of any real property to allow grass, weeds, and similar plants to grow on said property to a height in excess of ten inches. It shall be the duty and responsibility of every such owner, occupant or person in possession to keep the property clean and to remove from the premises all such abandoned or prohibited items listed in this article, including, but not limited to, dead trees, trash, rubbish, garbage, and the like. (c) It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in possession of any real property to allow a swimming pool, wading pool, hot tub or any similar structure to be in disrepair such that water can stand in the pool or structure and become a breeding ground for mosquitoes. All pools and similar structures must be in good operating condition with the water filtered and chlorinated or fully covered and any exposed water in the pool, structure or on the cover must be treated to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes. (d) The owner, tenant, or person in possession of any real property may be punished as provided in section 1-11 for a violation of this section. Until notice is given as set out in this section, only one violation shall be prosecuted for each transaction. After notice is given in compliance with the provisions of this section, if the violation continues, each day after the notice is received shall constitute a separate violation. (e) After giving proper notice of a violation and five business days thereafter to correct the deficiencies, the county shall have the authority to enter the property and bring such structure into compliance with these regulations. The expense of such city action shall be charged against the property owner, become a lien on the property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. If the property is owned by a homeowners association or similar entity, the city may place liens upon the property of the homeowners. The amount of the lien placed upon the property of each homeowner shall a pro rata share of the expense of said city action. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-202), 10-13-2008) Sec. 28-23. - Abandoned or vacant buildings to be secured. (a) The owner or person in possession of any abandoned or vacant buildings or structures shall secure and board up such buildings or structures to prevent entry by animals, vermin or trespassers. The structure shall be deemed secure if the windows, doors and other openings are boarded up or in the case of solid doors, the doors are securely locked. (b) The owner, tenant, or person in possession of any real property may be punished as provided in section 1-11 for a violation of this section. Until notice is given as set out in this section, only one violation shall be prosecuted for each transaction. After notice is given in compliance with the provisions of this section, if the violation continues, each day after the notice is received shall constitute a separate violation. (c) After giving proper notice of a violation and five business days thereafter to correct the deficiencies, the city shall have the authority to enter the property and bring it into compliance with these regulations. The expense of such city action shall be charged against the property owner, become a lien on the property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. If the property is owned by a homeowners association or similar entity, the city may place liens upon the property of the homeowners. The amount of the lien placed upon the property of each homeowner shall a pro rata share of the expense of said city action. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-203), 10-13-2008) Sec. 28-24. - Parking or storage of commercial vehicles, buses, trailers, trucks or equipment. (a) In all residential zoning districts, the parking of the following commercial vehicles is prohibited: (1) Limousines; (2) Flat-bed trucks; (3) Dump trucks; (4) Tow trucks; (5) Transport wreckers; (6) Tandem axle trucks; (7) Cab-on-chassis trucks; (8) Tractor trailers; (9) Wheeled attachments or trailers; (10) Buses; (11) Earth-moving machinery; (12) Semi-trailers; and (13) Any vehicle over 20 feet in length, or seven feet in height, or seven feet in width. Vehicles or equipment used for agricultural purposes on agricultural zoned property with five or more acres are permitted if parked outside the required front yard setback. (b) In all residential zoning districts, the parking of the following commercial vehicles is permitted: (1) An automobile, pick-up truck, van or SUV used to provide daily transportation to and from work. (2) A commercial vehicle that is parked temporarily in conjunction with a commercial service, sale, delivery or pick-up. (c) In all residential zoning districts recreational vehicles or equipment, including noncommercial trailers, may be parked or stored only in the side yard or rear yard or in an enclosed building. No such recreational vehicle or equipment shall be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes when parked or stored on a residential lot, or in any location not approved for such use. (d) With the exception of recreational vehicles and commercial vehicles parked temporarily in conjunction with a service, sale, delivery or pick-up, no vehicle with more than six wheels or two axles or that weighs more than 14,000 pounds or that is over 20 feet in length, or seven feet in height, or seven feet in width shall be parked in a residential district. (e) The owner, tenant, or person in possession of any real property may be punished as provided in section 1-11 for a violation of this section. Until notice is given as set out in this section, only one violation shall be prosecuted for each transaction. After notice is given in compliance with the provisions of this section, if the violation continues, each day after the notice is received shall constitute a separate violation. (f) After giving proper notice of a violation and five business days thereafter to correct the deficiencies, the city shall have the authority to enter the property and bring it into compliance with these regulations by impounding any vehicle found parked on the property in violation of this section. The expense of such county action shall be charged against the property owner, become a lien on the property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. If the property is owned by a homeowners association or similar entity, the city may place liens upon the property of the homeowners. The amount of the lien placed upon the property of each homeowner shall a pro rata share of the expense of said city action. The impounded vehicle may be reclaimed by the vehicle's owner who shall be responsible for payment of the towing and storage fees, otherwise the vehicle shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-204), 10-13-2008) Sec. 28-25. - Off-road parking or storage of unlicensed or inoperable vehicles, trailers or equipment. (a) The owner, occupant or person in possession of real property within a residential zoned district shall not allow vehicles or trailers of any kind to be parked thereon without current license plates, unless such vehicle is parked within a fully enclosed garage or carport attached to the residence. (b) The owner or occupant of real property within a residential zoned district shall not allow any vehicles, trailers or other motorized equipment to remain in an inoperable condition for more than 30 days unless such vehicle, trailer or other motorized equipment is parked within a fully enclosed garage or carport attached to the residence. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section for a vehicle or trailer to be without one or more wheels or tires, or be in a state of disrepair for more than 30 days. (c) The owner or occupant of real property within a residential zoned district shall not allow any vehicles or trailers to be covered so as to obscure the license plate unless such vehicle or trailer is parked within a fully enclosed garage or carport attached to the residence. (d) The owner, tenant, or person in possession of any real property may be punished as provided in section 1-11 for a violation of this section. Until notice is given as set out in this section, only one violation shall be prosecuted for each transaction. After notice is given in compliance with the provisions of this section, if the violation continues, each day after the notice is received shall constitute a separate violation. (e) After giving proper notice of a violation and five business days thereafter to correct the deficiencies, the county shall have the authority to enter the property and bring it into compliance with these regulations by impounding any vehicle found parked on the property in violation of this section. The expense of such city action shall be charged against the property owner, become a lien on the property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. If the property is owned by a homeowners association or similar entity, the city may place liens upon the property of the homeowners. The amount of the lien placed upon the property of each homeowner shall a pro rata share of the expense of said city action. The impounded vehicle may be reclaimed by the vehicle's owner who shall be responsible for payment of the towing and storage fees, otherwise the vehicle shall be disposed of in accordance with state law. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-205), 10-13-2008) Sec. 28-26. - Property of dispossessed tenant or mortgagor to be removed within 48 hours of the date and time of execution of the writ of possession. (a) Personal property of a dispossessed tenant or dispossessed mortgagor must be removed from the property of the plaintiff in the writ of possession within 48 hours from the date and time the writ of possession is executed pursuant to article V of chapter 36. (b) After the expiration of 48 hours from the date and time the writ of possession was executed, the city street department, or any other employee or agent designated by the council, shall have the authority to enter the property and bring it into compliance with these regulations by removing the abandoned personal property of a dispossessed tenant or dispossessed mortgagor to the county landfill or such other place as may be designated by the council. The expense of such city action shall be charged against the real property and become a lien on the real property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. If the property is owned by a homeowners association or similar entity, the city may place liens upon the property of the homeowners. The amount of the lien placed upon the property of each homeowner shall be a pro rata share of the expense of said city action. (Ord. No. 2008-14, pt. II(62-206), 10-13-2008)

div.head: Chapter 30 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 30-1. - False emergency alarms. (a) No person shall intentionally make, turn in or give a false alarm of need for ambulance assistance, or aid or abet in the commission of such act. The terms "aid" and "abet" shall be defined by reference to state law. (b) Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, sentenced in accordance with section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2001-14, § 3(62-2), 10-15-2001) State Law reference— False alarms, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-10-27, 16-10-29. Sec. 30-2. - Public drinking or consumption of alcoholic beverages. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages while on or in any public right-of-way or upon any way that the public has access to, including private parking areas open to the general public. It shall also be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages upon any city-owned property. (b) Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, sentenced in accordance with section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2001-14, § 5(62-8), 10-15-2001) State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 30-3. - Disorderly conduct. (a) A person commits the offense of disorderly conduct when he: (1) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another in such a way that an immediate breach of the peace is promoted; (2) Endangers, inhibits or obstructs the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, threats or abusive conduct; (3) Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct likely to promote an immediate breach of the peace or cause public alarm; (4) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl or promoting a breach of the peace; (5) Jostles, roughly crowds or pushes any person in public; (6) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose or with the intent to engage in gaming; (7) Frequents any public place with intent to obtain money from other persons by illegal or fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; (8) Assembles for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place not owned, leased or rented by the actor or from any person in said city, or aids or abets therein; (9) Utters in the presence of another, any bawdy, lewd or obscene words or epithets under such circumstances that said utterance is likely to produce an immediate breach of the peace; (10) Frequents any place where gaming or illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, marijuana, narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated; (11) Acts in a dangerous manner toward others in a manner that is reasonably likely, under the totality of the circumstances, to promote an immediate breach of the peace or cause public alarm; (12) Uses fighting words while on property not his own or in the presence of persons not members of his family within the third degree of consanguinity or affinity and directed towards any other person; (13) By acts of violence, interferes with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; (14) Congregates with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered by a law enforcement officer or other lawful authority; (15) Interferes with any game, sporting event, athletic contest at a publicly-owned or operated park or recreational facility through speech or actions that reasonably cause concern for the safety of observers or attendees; physically interferes with the participants in such event or goes upon the playing field or area and refuses to leave when directed to do so by an officiating person, participant or person with supervisory authority over the event or contest; (16) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby the property of such person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed. The term "property," as used in this section, shall be defined as any item of realty or personalty in which another has an interest of any type. Such interest shall include, but not be limited to, an interest created by legal title, equitable interest, divided or otherwise, an interest created by a certificate of stock, an interest created by a contract for insurance, direct ownership or such other interest; (17) Refuses to depart a commercial establishment after being told to do so by an owner, employee or agent of the commercial establishment for any reason not prohibited by law, including inappropriate attire. No prosecution shall be initiated under this provision if the attire in question was related to express the faith of the person. (b) Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the peaceful assembly of citizens in a lawful manner, and/or the free exercise of protected speech, nor shall the mere possibility of disorder justify the exclusion of persons otherwise entitled to be present. (c) Law enforcement officers shall have the authority to arrest for a violation of this section pursuant to state law. (d) Any person convicted of disorderly conduct shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 and six months' incarceration, or both. The trial court may suspend or probate any portion of the aforementioned fine or incarceration and may impose conditions of suspension or probation as are, among others, reasonable in preventing another occurrence of disorderly conduct and protect the peace and dignity of the city. (Ord. of 10-15-2002, § 1(62-9); Ord. No. 2008-09, pt. 1, §§ 1, 2, 7-14-2008) State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 30-4. - Graffiti prohibition and abatement. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Graffiti means any letters, abbreviations, numbers, figures, pictures, emblems, symbols, or other defacements that are marked, written, inscribed, scratched, painted, sprayed, drawn, or otherwise placed upon any surface of property by means of paint, brushes, aerosol sprays, markers, labels, paint sticks, chalk, or any device capable of scarring or leaving any visible mark upon any surface. Owner means any person owning, controlling, maintaining or preserving property as defined herein. In the case of property owned by non-natural entities, any officer, manager, supervisor, partner is to be considered an owner. Property means real property; improvements or structures thereon; vehicles; powered or unpowered; fences; walls; driveways; whether personalty, realty or fixtures to realty. (b) Prohibited acts. (1) It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to place or cause graffiti to be placed on any property, whether publicly or privately owned, managed, or possessed; (2) It shall be unlawful for any owner of any property within the limits of the city to allow any graffiti to be placed upon his property when such graffiti is visible to persons not on such property after such person has been given written notice; (3) It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon, enter, attempt to go upon or enter the property of another for the purpose of placing graffiti upon or in said property; (4) It shall be unlawful for any person to possess material or equipment for the purposes of placing graffiti on any property. In the trial of a violation of this subsection, the court may consider the amount and type of material or equipment possessed; the circumstances under which the equipment or material was possessed, including, but not limited to, the location, hour, concealment, demeanor of the accused, and any explanation provided by the accused. (c) Placing graffiti; penalty. Any person who is convicted of placing graffiti shall be guilty of a violation and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both such fine and imprisonment. The court may suspend or probate a portion or its entire sentence upon such conditions to include, but not be limited to, the restoring of the property so defaced, damaged or destroyed, or other remedial action. No fine or punishment shall accrue to a business or individual who is in compliance with the terms and conditions of any sign permit. (d) Notice to remove graffiti. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, entity, or utility owner, or any person, firm, entity, or utility owner acting as a manager, tenant, or agent for the owner of the property, to fail to remove graffiti within 30 days after written notice is given. (2) Whenever the city becomes aware of the existence of graffiti or other unsightly conditions on any property, including structures or improvements within the city, a police officer, code enforcement officer or other person authorized by the mayor, shall give or cause to be given, written notice to the property owner, and/or owner's agent, tenant, or manager to remove such graffiti or other unsightly condition therefrom. (3) The notice required by this section may be served by personal service, or registered or certified mail addressed to the owner at the last known address of said owner. If the last known address of the owner cannot be determined, the notice shall be sent to the property address. Such notice shall allow 30 days from the date of the notice for removal of identified graffiti. (4) For the purposes of giving the notice to the owner of the property, the person shown as the owner of said property on the ad valorem tax records of the county shall be sent such notice at the address shown thereon unless the city receives actual notice that another person owns said property. In addition, the owner may notify the city that the tenant, pursuant to a written lease, has control of the property or has control of that portion of the property which is the subject matter of this article and, in the event the city receives such notice, the city shall notify the tenant of the notice of removal as provided in this article and proceed against the tenant and not the owner. Provided, however, as to any violation of this article in existence prior to the date of approval of this article, any notice of removal shall give 60 days for the removal thereof. (5) For the purposes of giving notice as required by this section, if the graffiti is placed upon a commercial structure or is otherwise located upon commercial property, service may be perfected by personal service on any employee, officer, partner, supervisor or owner of the business located at the commercial site, together with a notice sent by first class mail to the address of the business or commercial site, addressed to the applicant for a business license or owner of the site according to county tax records, if no business is located at that site. (6) If the graffiti is located on the property, equipment, pole, or other object owned by a public utility, providing electric power, natural or propane gas, water, telephone service, trash or waste removal, notice shall be by first class mail to the address provided to the city for emergency contact. (7) Corporate prosecutions. (8) A property owner that has received proper written notice of the presence of graffiti on the property shall have 30 days from the date of that written notice to remove the graffiti themselves or through the use of a private contractor. (e) Penalties for failure to remove graffiti. Any person, firm, entity, or utility owner, or any person, firm, entity, or utility owner acting as a manager, tenant, or agent for the owner of the property that fails to remove graffiti before the expiration of the 30 days following written notice as provided by this article shall be issued a summons to appear in the municipal court of the city, in order to have determined there whether that person, firm, entity, or utility owner, or any person, firm, entity, or utility owner acting as a manager, tenant, or agent for the owner of the property is in violation of the provisions of this section. Any person, firm, entity, or utility owner, or any person, firm, entity, or utility owner acting as a manager, tenant, or agent for the owner of the property that is adjudged to be in violation of this article shall be guilty of a violation and shall be subject to a fine of not to exceed a total of $1,000.00, or by imprisonment not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. No. 2008-08, pt. 2, § 1(62-10), 7-14-2008) Sec. 30-5. - Child curfew. (a) Title. This section shall be known as the "City Child Curfew Ordinance." (b) Findings and purpose. (1) It is the responsibility of the mayor, council and employees of the city to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city ("city," hereinafter). The mayor and council are concerned about the increase in criminal activity engaged in by children and the increase in criminal activity that adversely affects children, especially criminal activity which occurs at hours and/or times after which children should be at home or in the company of responsible adults. The city and the county have experienced tragic and violent acts, involving serious injuries and even deaths, involving children in recent years, with many of these acts occurring after the hour set out herein for curfew. At numerous community meetings many citizens have voiced their concerns about the increase in child violence, the need to protect our children from being victims of crimes that occur after the hour set out in this section for curfew, and the need to make parents and adults more responsible for the children in their care. The mayor and council also find that there is a need to make other adults owning and operating certain establishments responsible for the presence of children at those establishments and locations. (2) In an effort to keep the city drug free and the city's streets safe by reducing the numbers of crimes that are committed by and against children after the hour set out in this section for curfew, the mayor and council find that a child curfew ordinance is one initiative to protect children in the city from being the victims, as well as perpetrators, of crime. (3) Accordingly, the mayor and council find and declare that the purpose of this section is to reduce the number of crimes committed by and against children, and to safeguard the welfare of our children in areas in the city after the hour set out in this section for curfew; it, therefore, enacts a child curfew ordinance as hereinafter set forth in the best interest of the citizens of the city. (c) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult means a person who is at least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor, or an emancipated minor. Child means any person 17 years of age or under. Curfew hours means 11:00 p.m., on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. the following day, and 12:00 midnight on any Friday or Saturday until 6:00 a.m. the following day. Emancipated minor means: (1) Any person under the age of 18 years who is or has been married or who is not under the care, custody, and control of a parent, parents, guardian, person standing in loco parentis, or the juvenile court of competent jurisdiction; or (2) Any person under the age of 18 years who has had the disabilities of minority removed by a court of competent jurisdiction. Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term "emergency" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life or further serious bodily injury or loss of life. Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. Guardian means a person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor, or a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court. Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and officers of a corporation. Parent means a person who is a natural parent, an adopted parent, or stepparent of another person. Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access that includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. Remain means to linger, to stay, or to fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a law-enforcement officer or the owner, operator, or the person in control of the premises. Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that causes death or creates a substantial risk of serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. (d) Curfew for persons 17 years of age or younger. (1) It is unlawful for any child to loiter, to wander, to stroll, or to play in or upon any public place, street, highway, road, alley, park, playground or other public ground, establishment, public building, place of amusement, eating place, vacant lot, or any other place in the city unsupervised by an adult, parent, or guardian having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m., on every day and 6:00 a.m., the following day, except, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., the following day. (2) It is unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child to knowingly, or by insufficient control, to allow such minor to be in or upon any public place, or any other place listed in subsection (d)(1) of this section in the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m., on every day and 6:00 a.m., the following day, except, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., the following day, except as provided by subsection (e)(4) of this section. (3) It is unlawful for any owner, operator, or employee of an establishment to knowingly allow a child to be in or upon the premises of an establishment in the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m., on every day and 6:00 a.m., the following day, except, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., the following day, except as provided by subsection (e)(4) of this section. (e) Offenses. (1) A child commits an offense, if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. (2) A parent or a guardian of a child commits an offense, if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the child to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. (3) An owner, operator, or employee of an establishment commits an offense, if he knowingly allows a child to remain in or upon the premises of any establishment in the city during curfew hours. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the local law enforcement that a child was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. (4) Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: a. When a child is accompanied by his parent, guardian, or other adult having the lawful care and custody of the child; b. When the child is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such child, or if such child is seeking medical treatment; c. When the child is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity, or dance; d. When the child is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above referenced places during the prescribed period of time; e. When the child is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; f. When the child is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel; g. When the child is an emancipated minor. (f) Penalties. (1) Upon the conviction of a violation of this section by an adult, parent, or guardian, or an owner, operator or employee of an establishment, there shall be a fine, not to exceed $1,000.00, or imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. Except as may otherwise be provided, each violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. (2) Adjudication of violations of this section by a child shall be made in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 15-11-1 et seq. (g) Enforcement. Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a law enforcement officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and the reason for being in the public place. Furthermore, the officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstance, no exception listed in subsection (e)(4) of this section is present. (Ord. No. 2008-07, pt. 1, § 1(62-11), 7-14-2008) Sec. 30-6. - Dumping, depositing, etc., litter on public or private property or waters. (a) Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to protect the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare through the regulation and prevention of litter. The objectives of this section are to: (1) Provide for uniform prohibition throughout the city of any and all littering on public or private property; and (2) Prevent the desecration of the beauty and quality of life of the city and prevent harm to the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare, including the degradation of water and aquatic resources caused by litter. (b) Applicability. This section shall apply to all public and private property within the city. (c) Compatibility with other regulations. This section is not intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision of law. The requirements of this section should be considered minimum requirements, and where any provision of this section imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive or impose higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall be considered to take precedence. (d) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Litter means any organic or inorganic waste material, rubbish, refuse, garbage, trash, hulls, peelings, debris, grass, weeds, ashes, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, metal, plastic, and glass containers, broken glass, dead animals or intentionally or unintentionally discarded materials of every kind and description which are not "waste" as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-7-51(6). Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; timberlands or forests; and residential, commercial, industrial, or farm properties. (e) Prohibition against littering public or private property or waters. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, throw or leave, or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of, litter on any public or private property in the city or any waters in the city unless: (1) The property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property; (2) The litter is placed into a receptacle or container installed on such property; or (3) The person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. (f) Violations, enforcement and penalties. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this section. Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this section may be subject to the enforcement actions outlined in this subsection (f) or may be restrained by injunction or otherwise sentenced in a manner provided by law. (2) Evidence. a. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance in violation of this ordinance, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this ordinance. b. Except as provided in subsection (f)(2)a of this section, whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this section is discovered to contain any article or articles, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writing which display the name of the person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this section. (3) Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: a. By a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $1,200.00; b. In addition to the fine set out in subsection (f)(3)a of this section, the violator shall reimburse the city for the reasonable cost of removing the litter when the litter is or is ordered removed by the city; and c. 1. In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of way for a distance not to exceed one mile any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or 2. In the sound discretion of the court, the person may be directed to pick up and remove any and all litter from any public property, private right-of-way, or with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter. Pick up and removal shall include any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; and d. The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating this section in a newspaper of general publication within the city. (4) Enforcement. All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of this state or any political subdivision thereof, or any enforcement agency, officer or any official of any commission of this state or any political subdivision thereof, are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this section. (Ord. of 10-15-2002, § 3(62-30); Ord. No. 06-13, §§ 1—3, 5, 4-11-2006) State Law reference— Littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-17-42 et seq. Sec. 30-7. - Public nudity prohibited. (a) A person over the age of 12 years who knowingly or intentionally does any of the following in a public place commits public nudity: (1) Appears in a state of nudity; (2) Urinates in a public place so that the genitals are seen by another; (3) Any individual exposing a breast in the process of breast feeding an infant under two years of age shall not be guilty of the offense of public nudity. (b) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Nudity means the showing of the human male or female genital, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple; the exposure of any device, costume, or covering which gives the appearance of or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, natal cleft, perineum anal region or pubic hair region; or the exposure of any device worn as a cover over the nipples and/or areola of the female breast, which device simulates and gives the realistic appearance of nipples and/or areola. Public place means and includes all outdoor places owned by or open to the general public, and all buildings and enclosed places owned by or open to the general public, including such places of entertainment, taverns, restaurants, clubs, theaters, dance halls, banquet halls, party rooms or halls limited to specific members, restricted to adults or to patrons invited to attend, whether or not an admission charge is levied, but shall not include restrooms or areas in structures designed and used exclusively for persons to change clothing. (Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1(62-40), 6-13-2006) Sec. 30-8. - Interference with operation of school bus. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: School bus means any vehicle designed for the transportation of students of a school system, owned or operated by a public school system of this state, whether or not the bus is occupied by passengers. Students means authorized passengers of a school bus, as defined above, whether or not they are enrolled in a public school system of this state. (b) It shall be a violation of this Code to: (1) Impede or obstruct the movement of a school bus in the city or the boarding or discharge of students from a school bus in the city. (2) Engage in any conduct on or about a school bus in the city, in the presence of students on a school bus in the city, or in the presence of students boarding or being discharged from a school bus in the city, which may reasonably be seen as likely to be immediately detrimental to the peace, good order or safety of the students. (3) Board a school bus in the city without permission for the purpose of engaging in any conduct which may reasonably be seen as likely to be immediately detrimental to the peace, good order or safety of the students. (4) Knowingly follow a school bus in the city at such a time and manner that a reasonable person would believe would create in the driver or students of the school bus an apprehension of either the students or driver suffering an assault or battery. (Ord. of 10-15-2002, § 7(62-45)) Sec. 30-9. - Unlawful activity near railroad. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter about or upon railroad tracks or in railroad shops within the city or to swing onto trains for the purpose of securing a free ride thereon. A person commits the offense of loitering upon the railroad tracks when he is in the vicinity of the railroad at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. (Ord. of 11-12-2012, § 1(62-50))

div.head: Chapter 32 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 32-1. - General provisions and definitions. (a) The city or its designee shall be responsible for maintaining and regulating use of all publicly owned parks and recreational facilities in the city. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Department means the city or its designee, including the county department of parks and recreation. Parks means all parks and all facilities located thereon, which are owned or controlled by the city and operated under the jurisdiction of the city or its designee. Person means any individual, citizen, group, association, firm, corporation or other legal entity who is authorized to use and enjoy the city's parks and any structure or facility located thereon. (Ord. No. 2001-15, § 2(66-1), 10-15-2001) Secs. 32-2—32-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COMMUNITY RECREATION DEPARTMENT
Sec. 32-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Center means the city's community recreation center. Department means the city community recreation department. Department director means the director of the community recreation department. (Ord. No. 2006-05, art. I, § 1, 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 06, pt. III(art. I, § 1), 6-9-2008) Sec. 32-22. - Community recreation department created; budget; supervision. (a) Creation. There shall be a department within the city's government created known as the "Lovejoy Community Recreation Department." The department shall be responsible for the following: (1) Operation of the center; (2) Planning and execution of recreational and other community-oriented programs to benefit the citizens of the city; (3) Planning and execution of programs designed to benefit the youth and the senior citizens of the city; (4) Such other duties as are designed to deliver services to the city's citizens through education, recreation, or community service. (b) Budget. (1) There shall be a separate account established for the department within the city budget. The account shall contain an expenditures component and a revenue component. (2) All revenues and incomes received by the city derived from the rental of the center, community or recreational activities conducted by the department, donations, grants, and other contributions to the city intended for recreational and community use shall be placed in the revenue account of the department's budget and shall not be expended for the purposes not related to the department's duties and business. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the mayor and council or their designee from the use of any physical asset of the department for other official city use on a temporary basis. Nothing contained herein shall prevent the mayor and council from providing additional funding from authorized sources to the department. (c) Supervision of department. (1) Appointment; duties and responsibilities. a. The mayor and council may appoint a director of community recreation. In the absence of said appointment, supervision of the department shall be provided for as the mayor and council may direct or pursuant to other ordinances and the city's Charter. The director shall direct the operations of the department and shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 1. Supervision of department employees, including recommendations on personnel action to the mayor and council; 2. Management of the center and such other facilities dedicated to community recreation that the city may own or operate; 3. Receipt, maintenance and accounting of the funds and assets of the department; forwarding of all funds and revenues to the proper city official as may be prescribed by the mayor and council; 4. Such other duties and responsibilities that may be prescribed by the mayor and council or their designee. b. The mayor and council shall create a job description for the director, outlining in reasonable specificity the duties and responsibilities of that position. (2) Advisors for special programs. There shall be created a position of advisor for senior citizen programs and a position of advisor for youth programs. The advisors shall provide to the administrative assistant, mayor and council information concerning programs of the department concerning senior citizens and youth. The advisors shall act as a liaison between the city and persons concerned with such programs. The mayor and council may, by resolution, create such other advisory positions as they relate to other special programs by the department. Ay such advisors shall be compensated in the amount of $50.00 per calendar month in order to assist in defraying expenses on the part of the advisors. (3) The mayor and council may create and fund such other positions as are deemed necessary and proper within the department. (Ord. No. 2006-05, art. I, § 2, 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 06, pt. III(art. I, § 2), 6-9-2008) Secs. 32-23—32-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES RELATED TO COMMUNITY RECREATION CENTER
Sec. 32-41. - Loitering at a recreation center or facility. (a) It shall be unlawful to loiter about a recreational facility of the city without a valid, lawful purpose for his presence there. Among the factors that the trier of fact may consider in determining the validity of said person's presence are the activity or lack of activity taking place at the facility at the time; the time of day and day of week of said person's presence; flight upon approach by law enforcement officers or other persons; concealment of any item or substance; the presence of any weapon or device that may appear to be intended for use as a weapon; intoxication of the person, and any other factor that may cause a reasonable person to have alarm for the public safety and order under the circumstances. (b) Upon determining that a person has committed the offense of loitering at a recreation center or facility, a law enforcement officer is hereby authorized to and shall instruct the offender to remove himself from the facility or center instanter. Such law enforcement is hereby authorized by the mayor and council to notify such person that he is not allowed to come upon the premises of any city recreation center or facility in the future. (c) Upon conviction, a person may be punished by imposition of a fine, incarceration, or other such punishment up to and including the maximum provided by law. (Ord. No. 2006-05, art. III, § 1(62-50), 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 06, pt. III(art. III, § 1(62-46)), 6-9-2008) Sec. 32-42. - Unlawful parking of motor vehicles at recreational center or facility. (a) It shall be unlawful to stop, park, stand or otherwise permit a vehicle to be parked upon the premises of a city recreation center or facility: (1) So that said vehicle blocks or otherwise obstructs ingress or egress to or from the center or facility; (2) So that said vehicle blocks or otherwise obstructs the travel of vehicular or pedestrian traffic upon the premises of the center or facility; (3) After the posted operating hours of the center or facility. (b) In the event a vehicle blocks ingress or egress to a city recreation center or facility, a peace officer may order the car removed to an impound facility after a reasonable attempt to locate the owner or authorized operator and have the vehicle removed. (c) Upon conviction, a person violating this section may be punished by a fine, incarceration or both, up to and including the maximum provided by law. (Ord. No. 2006-05, art. III, § 1(62-51), 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 06, pt. III(art. III, § 1(62-47)), 6-9-2008) Sec. 32-43. - Possession of knives and other devices upon city recreation center or facility property. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any knife with a blade more than three inches long, any butterfly knife, or any other type knife or object designed, modified or commonly used for offense or defense, at any city recreation center or facility. This section shall not prohibit the possession of knives or cutting implements possessed by invited attendees at such a center or facility for the purpose of preparation or serving of food while at the center or facility. (b) Upon conviction, a person violating this section may be punished by a fine, incarceration or both, up to and including the maximum provided by law. (c) Upon finding a device prohibited by this section in the possession of a person upon a city recreation center or facility, and it reasonably appearing to a law enforcement officer that the possession of the object was for the purpose of offense or defense at the recreation facility or center, said officer is hereby authorized by the mayor and council to escort said person from the facility or center and notify him that he is not to come upon the premises of any city recreation center or facility in the future. (Ord. No. 2006-05, art. III, § 1(62-52), 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 06, pt. III(art. III, § 1(62-48)), 6-9-2008)

div.head: Chapter 34 - PERSONNEL
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 34-1—34-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CODE OF ETHICS
Sec. 34-19. - Zoning. All officials subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 67A (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.) shall make the disclosures therein required and shall be subject to the penalties therein stated. In addition, any official required to make the disclosures set forth in such provisions of O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 67A (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.) shall be prohibited from participating in the zoning matter in which such official or employee has a direct or indirect interest. A violation of the provisions of the O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 67A (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.) shall also constitute a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 14(70-70), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-20. - Campaign contributions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to campaign contributions made to an official in compliance with or authorized by the Ethics in Government Act (O.C.G.A. § 21-5-1 et seq.). (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 15(70-71), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-21. - Conflict. To the extent any provision of this article conflicts with O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1 or any other laws or regulations of the United States or the state, such provision of this article shall be void and otherwise of no force or effect. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 18(70-74), 8-19-2002) Secs. 34-22—34-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CITY EMPLOYEE ALCOHOL AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE POLICY DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 34-46. - Statement of policy. (a) The government of the city is firmly committed to providing its employees with a safe work place and promoting high standards of employee health. Consistent with the spirit and intent of this commitment, the mayor and council have established this policy regarding alcohol and substance abuse. The mayor and council's goal will continue to be one of establishing and maintaining a work environment that is free from the effects of alcohol and substance abuse. (b) Government has several uniquely compelling interests that justify the implementation of procedures for employee alcohol and substance testing. The public has a right to expect that those who have the responsibility of providing services to taxpayers of the city are at all times both physically and mentally prepared to perform their assigned job duties. There is sufficient evidence to conclude that the use of alcohol and certain substances may seriously impair an employee's physical and mental health, and thus, job performance. Where employees participate in alcohol and substance abuse, the integrity of city government and public confidence therein is destroyed. (c) The city recognizes that employees have privacy interests and certain privacy rights in their medical condition and treatment. The city respects those interests and rights as long as the privacy of those matters does not impact the safety of the citizens of the city, the safety employees, and the delivery of city services. (d) Therefore, in order to ensure the integrity of the city's government and to preserve public trust and confidence, the mayor and council hereby implements an alcohol and substance abuse policy and testing program to detect prohibited alcohol and substance use by city employees and those persons performing services on behalf of the city. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 30(70-126), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 2(70-126), 5-11-2009) Secs. 34-47—34-65. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - REGULATIONS
Sec. 34-66. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. For the purpose of this division, the term "alcohol" shall include distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage or fortified wine. Chain of custody means procedures to account for the integrity of each specimen by tracking its handling and storage from point of specimen collection to fine disposition of the specimen. These procedures shall not be required to negative any possibility of contamination, but shall ensure to a reasonable certainty that the sample remains identifiable and untainted.
