Collection site means the facility or location designated by the city (or any alternate site authorized by this division) where individuals present themselves for the purpose of providing a specimen of their blood, breath or urine to be analyzed for the presence of alcohol or substances. Collection site person means personnel under the direction of the facility or location staff or personnel employed by any alternate collection site authorized by this division, who will instruct and assist individuals at a collection site and who will receive and make an initial examination of the specimen provided by those individuals. A collection site person shall be familiar with the procedures with collection and preservation of samples of bodily substances. Confirmatory test means a second analytical procedure to identify the presence of a specific substance or metabolite which is independent of the initial test and which may use a different technique and chemical principle from that of the initial test in order to ensure reliability and accuracy. Controlled substance means those substances as defined in the state Controlled Substances Act (O.C.G.A. § 16-13-20 et seq.). The term "controlled substance" shall include marijuana as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-21. Department head means the senior person in a department of the city, supervising the activities of that department. Employee means those individuals who occupy a position in city government or performing services on behalf of any private or corporate entity on behalf of the city. Initial test (also known as screening test) means an immunoassay screen to eliminate negative specimens from further consideration. Permanent record book means a book or log in which identifying data on each specimen collected at a collection site is permanently recorded in the sequence of collection. Reasonable suspicion means that quantity or proof of evidence that is more than a hunch, but less than probable cause. Reasonable suspicion must be based on specific, objective facts and any rationally derived inferences from those facts about the conduct of an individual that would lead a reasonable person to suspect that the individual is or has been using alcohol or controlled substances while on or off duty. Test, alcohol or substance, means the compulsory production and submission of blood, breath or urine by an employee in accordance with city government procedures for chemical analysis to detect prohibited alcohol and/or substance usage. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 33(70-136), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 4(70-136), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-67. - Alcohol and substance use prohibited. (a) Except as hereafter provided, the use, possession, sale, distribution or provision of alcohol or any controlled substance during work time or on the work premises shall be prohibited. This provision shall not apply to employees when such use, possession, sale, distribution or provision of alcohol or any controlled substance is an incident to the employees' lawful duties or is otherwise required in the normal course of their employment. (b) Reporting to work or working while under the influence or otherwise impaired by alcohol or any controlled substance shall be prohibited. (c) Alcohol or controlled substance-related off-duty use that tends to undermine the reputation, authority or efficiency of the city government is prohibited. (d) The use or possession of prescription drugs while on the work premises or while working shall be prohibited unless the prescription container does not have a warning that the contents should not be used when operating equipment or motor vehicles, may cause drowsiness, or any other warning that may describe a reaction to the contents that would reasonably be expected to impair the ability of the employee to perform his duties safely and effectively. If such a warning was on the prescription container when filled, then the employee shall ensure that: (1) The prescribing physician has been notified of the duties involved with the employee's position and has approved the use of the drug while that employee is performing those duties; and (2) The employee's immediate supervisor has been notified in writing by the employee that he is using a prescription drug and that the employee's physician has approved the use of the drug while the employee is at work. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 34(70-137), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 4(70-137), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-68. - Alcohol and/or substance testing. (a) Alcohol and/or substance testing may be required of job applicants for positions which deal with public safety; or which require or permit the use of motor vehicles or heavy equipment; or which would pose a threat of bodily harm to the applicant; coworkers or the general public if the applicant was impaired. Whether a particular position comes within the meaning of this section will be determined by the city manager in consultation with the department head, or at the direction of the mayor. At the time applications for any position covered by this section are received, the applicant will be informed that employment is conditional upon alcohol or substance testing. The term "applicant" shall include any current employee of the city that is applying for any position covered by this section as well as any person not a current employee of the city. (b) Alcohol and/or substance testing will be required of employees for which reasonable suspicion exists to believe that such employees are under the influence of alcohol or substances during assigned working hours or while otherwise on city property. Testing may be required following work-related accidents if the surrounding circumstances give rise to reasonable suspicion to believe that such employees are under the influence of alcohol or substances. (1) The initial determination of whether or not reasonable suspicion exists shall be made by the department head or by the highest ranking supervisory staff person on duty at the time. The department head or supervisory staff person shall consult with the city manager (or city clerk in the absence of the city manager), when available, for the purpose of determining if an alcohol or substance test is appropriate under the circumstances. (2) Following the determination that reasonable suspicion exists and an alcohol or substance test should be administered, the employee shall be immediately transported to the collection site by the employee's department head or such designee of the department director. Following the collection procedure, the person transporting the employee shall make appropriate arrangements to transport the employee home. (3) Public safety department heads and their designees shall not be required to consult with the city manager prior to making a determination that reasonable suspicion exists, inasmuch as those individuals and their designees have specific training qualifying them to make such determinations. Accordingly, when a public safety department head or designee makes the determination that reasonable suspicion exists, the employee shall be immediately transported to the collection site as is provided hereinabove. (4) Any employee tested under this provision may be suspended without pay for up to three days pending the results of the test. If the results of the test are negative, the employee shall return to work with complete restoration of lost salary. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 35(70-138), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 4(70-138), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-69. - Employment action when applicant or employee tests positive. (a) Applicants testing positive. Applicants testing positive shall not be employed at that time. Applicants that are denied employment for this reason may reapply for employment after six months from the date of the positive substance test, if meeting all other requirements for application. The fact that the applicant previously had a positive result in a test for drugs or alcohol shall not itself preclude employment with the city but may be considered upon reapplication. (b) Employees testing positive. Employees testing positive shall be subject to the following employment action: (1) Termination of employment; or (2) Suspension without pay. (c) Probation. All employees not terminated following a positive test shall be placed on probation for one year following the date of testing. Probationary employees shall be subject to testing without prior notice at irregular intervals throughout the term of the employee's probation. Probationary testing shall be directed by the city manager at the request of the department head. The city manager, in consultation with the department head shall determine the dates of the probationary tests and shall inform the employee when to report for testing. This testing will in no event be more frequent than twice in any given month. The foregoing provision shall not prevent testing that exceeds twice monthly if reasonable suspicion exists for testing. (d) Failure to appear for testing. Failure to appear at the designated collection site when directed or other failure to take the test shall subject the employee or applicant to the same sanctions as if the test had been positive or may be considered insubordination. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 36(70-139), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 4(70-139), 5-11-2009) Secs. 34-70—34-96. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - GUIDELINES FOR TESTING
Sec. 34-97. - Drugs and substances tested for. (a) Every specimen shall at a minimum be tested for marijuana, amphetamines and cocaine. (b) Specimens may be tested for opiates, amphetamines, phencyclidine and alcohol. (c) When conducting reasonable suspicion, accident or probationary testing, specimens may be tested for any substance. (d) For the purposes of this section, testing shall be deemed to include the authority to test for the metabolites of substances, also. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 39(70-151), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-151), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-98. - Specimen collection procedures. The following provisions outline procedures for specimen collection: (1) The collection site shall have the personnel and materials necessary to collect specimens and maintain the integrity of them. The site and procedures shall comply with the chain of custody requirements as defined in section 34-66. (2) Procedures for collecting urine specimens shall allow individual privacy unless there is reason to believe that a particular individual may alter or substitute the specimen provided. (3) Collection site personnel shall take reasonable precautions to ensure that a specimen is not adulterated or diluted during the collection procedure, and that information on the specimen bottle and in the record book can identify the individual from whom the specimen was collected. (4) After the specimen is collected, it shall be properly sealed and labeled. Markings and documentation of the specimen shall reasonably identify the specimen and date. (5) The specimens shall be placed in containers designed to reasonably minimize the possibility of damage during shipment; and those containers shall be securely sealed to reasonably eliminate the possibility of undetected tampering. The containers be marked with the date the specimens were sealed in the containers for shipment. The collection site personnel shall reasonably protect the specimen from adulteration. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 40(70-152), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-152), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-99. - Laboratory analysis procedures. The following provisions outline procedures for laboratory analyses: (1) Laboratories will use only procedures approved by the National Institute for Drug Abuse (NIDA). (2) The initial test shall use an immunoassay which meets the requirements of the Food and Drug Administration for commercial distribution. (3) All specimens identified as positive on the initial test shall be confirmed using gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) techniques. All confirmations shall be by quantitative analysis. Concentrations exceeding the linear region of the standard curve shall be documented in laboratory records as "greater than highest standard curve value." (4) Before any test result is reported (the results of initial tests, confirmatory tests or quality control data), it shall be reviewed and the test certified as an accurate report by the responsible individual. The report shall identify the alcohol/substances/metabolites tested for, whether positive or negative, the specimen number assigned by the collection site person and the substance testing laboratory specimen identification number. The results (positive or negative) for all specimens submitted at the same time to the laboratory shall be reported back to the personnel director. (5) The city manager shall provide the department head with the results of the test. (6) The laboratory shall report as negative all specimens which are negative on the initial test or negative on the confirmatory test. Only specimens confirmed positive shall be reported positive for alcohol or a specific substance. (7) City manager may request from the laboratory and the laboratory shall provide quantitation of test results. The laboratory may transmit results to the city manager by various electronic means (e.g., teleprinters, facsimile or computer) in a manner designed to ensure confidentiality of the information. Results may not be provided verbally by telephone. The laboratory must ensure the security of the data transmission and limit access to any data transmission, storage and retrieval system. (8) The laboratory shall send to the city manager a copy of the documents relating to a chain of custody attesting to the validity of the test reports. (9) Because some analyses deteriorate or are lost during freezing and/or storage, quantitation for a retest is not subject to the specific cutoff requirement but must provide data sufficient to confirm the presence of alcohol or the substance or metabolite. (10) The laboratory shall have qualified personnel available to testify in an administrative or disciplinary proceeding against an employee when that proceeding is based on positive results reported by the laboratory. (11) The provisions provided for in this article shall not limit the city to the usage of only the standard test described. This section shall not preclude tests for other substances and tests by other valid methodologies. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 41(70-153), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-153), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-100. - Quality assurance and quality control. Laboratories performing tests under this division shall have a quality assurance program which encompasses all aspects of the testing process, including, but not limited to, specimen acquisition, chain of custody, security and reporting of results, initial and confirmatory testing, and validation of analytical procedures. Quality assurance procedures shall be designed, implemented and reviewed to monitor the conduct of each step of the process of testing for substances. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 42(70-154), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-154), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-101. - Reporting and review of results. (a) Review by city manager, department head and trained medical personnel. The city manager shall review results in concert with the department head. An essential part of the substance testing program is the final review of results. A positive test result does not automatically identify an employee/applicant as an unauthorized alcohol or substance user. An individual with a detailed knowledge of possible alternate medical explanations is essential to the review of results. This review shall be performed in collaboration with trained medical personnel. (b) Discussion of positive results with individual; assessment of disciplinary action. Prior to making a final decision to verify a positive test result, the city manager with the department head shall give the individual an opportunity to discuss the test results. Following verification of positive test results, and in the absence of an appropriate alternate medical explanation, the department director shall assess appropriate disciplinary action against the employee. (c) Reanalysis of samples. Should any question arise as to the accuracy or validity of positive test results, the department head, in consultation with the city manager, is authorized to order a reanalysis of the original sample and such retests are authorized only at laboratories certified under these guidelines. (d) Certification of legitimate substance use. If the laboratory determines there is a legitimate medical explanation for the positive test results, it shall be certified that the results are consistent with authorized substance use and take no further action. If, however, the substance may impair the performance or safety of the employee or others, the department head is authorized to take appropriate action to eliminate any impairment of performance or safety concerns, not including disciplinary action. (e) Action upon determination of scientifically insufficient results. Additionally, the laboratory, based on a review inspection report, quality control data, multiple samples and other pertinent results, may determine that the results are scientifically insufficient for further action and declare the test specimen negative. In this situation, the head, in consultation with the city manager, may require reanalysis of the original sample specimen before making this decision. The reanalysis may be performed by the same laboratory, or a portion of the original specimen may be sent for reanalysis to alternate laboratory. The laboratory shall assist in this review process as requested by making available the individual responsible for day-to-day management of the substance testing laboratory or other employee who is a forensic toxicologist or who has equivalent forensic experience in substance testing to provide specific consultation as required by the city. The laboratory shall report to the city manager, who shall forward to the department head, all findings and the scientific basis therefor. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 43(70-155), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-155), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-102. - Alcohol testing. (a) When reasonable cause exists to believe that an employee is under the influence of alcohol, the following procedure for testing shall be employed: (1) The supervisor or other such person forming such reasonable belief shall immediately report the same to the department head. (2) The department head or his supervisor shall confer with the city manager as to the existence of a reasonable belief. For the reasons stated above, this provision shall not apply to public safety employees. (3) The employee shall be directed to submit to a test of his breath as soon as practicable after a determination of reasonable belief is made. (4) The testing of the employee's breath shall be performed on a device approved for breath testing pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-392, or approved for preliminary breath testing by the state department of public safety, the International Association of Chiefs of Police or the city police chief. (5) No less than two samples of the employee's breath shall be taken. If the testing device produces a printed test result, a copy of the same shall be provided to the employee. If there is no printed result, the results displayed on the device shall be shown to the employee and provided to the employee in writing, together with the time the samples were taken. (b) If the higher of the test results is .010 gms/ percent or higher, the employee shall not be returned to duty and shall be relieved from duty without pay for the remainder of the work day. If the higher test result is .020 gms/ percent or greater, the employee shall be relieved of duty and the city manager notified. (c) Failure or refusal to submit to breath testing when directed to by a proper authority shall subject the employee to disciplinary action. (Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-156), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-103. - Protection of employee records. The laboratory shall maintain employee records with the highest regard for employee privacy. The department head and city manager shall reveal the results of testing only to persons required under this Code. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 44(70-156), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-157), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-104. - Individual access to test and laboratory certification results. Any city employee who is the subject of an alcohol or substance test shall, upon written request, have access to any records relating to his alcohol or substance test. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 45(70-157), 8-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-158), 5-11-2009) Sec. 34-105. - Criminal prosecution. Nothing in this article shall preclude prosecution for any offense defined by state law or city ordinance. Nothing in this article shall prohibit city law enforcement employees electing to follow a procedure prescribed by state law instead of that set out hereinabove in testing city employees for drugs or alcohol. (Ord. No. 2009-04, § 6(70-159), 5-11-2009) Secs. 34-106—34-123. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - EMPLOYEE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (EAP)
Sec. 34-124. - Implementation. The reference point and clearinghouse for the employee assistance program (EAP) will be the county's personnel department. The EAP must have proper resources to interview employees and refer them to appropriate rehabilitation/treatment programs. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 48(70-171), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-125. - Confidentiality. The confidentiality of the records of the employee assistance program (EAP) coordinator will be ensured to further promote employee trust and confidence in the EAP. For the purposes of statistical reporting, names and dates will not be released. However, the EAP coordinator shall have the obligation to advise the department director (elected official) if such employee admits to be presently impaired. The notion of confidentiality does not give an impaired employee the right to continue working simply because he has accessed the EAP. In such a situation, the department director (elected official) may relieve the employee from work duty, and the employee may seek appropriate leave benefits or some other type of action that will not label the employee as an alcohol or substance abuser. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 49(70-172), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-126. - Supervisor referral. The alcohol and controlled substance abuse policy allows the department director (elected official) to refer an employee to the employee assistance program (EAP) rather than suspend or terminate the employee for a violation of the policy. All referrals to the EAP will be coordinated through the personnel department. After a decision to refer the employee to the EAP has been made, the employee shall be counseled by the department director (elected official) in concert with the personnel director. At this counseling session, the policy shall be reviewed with the employee, and the employee shall sign the employee consent and notice of referral form. The counseling session should further provide the opportunity to review the EAP expectations and all other available alternatives to participation in the EAP. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 50(70-173), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-127. - Financing. Subject to approval by the board of commissioners, an outside employee assistance program (EAP) professional organization may be retained as the EAP coordinator. All expenses incident to services rendered by the EAP coordinator shall be the sole responsibility of the employee referred to the EAP. However, the county will cooperate with the employee relative to the filing of appropriate claims with the employee's health insurance provider. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 51(70-174), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-128. - Employee's participation. (a) If participation in the employee assistance program (EAP) cannot be accomplished during nonworking hours, an employee may utilize accumulated sick and annual leave together with any other leave benefits afforded other similarly situated employees. (b) Upon their successful completion of the EAP, all employees referred to the EAP will be allowed to return to work with the reinstatement of all seniority rights and privileges previously enjoyed. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 52(70-175), 8-19-2002) Secs. 34-129—34-154. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SEXUAL HARASSMENT
Sec. 34-155. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to adopt a sexual harassment policy and to provide the procedure within which the objectives of this policy can be accomplished. Accordingly, pursuant to the guidelines of sex discrimination issued by the equal employment opportunity commission, the board of commissioners endorses the following policy. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 55(70-196), 8-19-2002) Sec. 34-156. - Policy statement. The following provisions shall constitute the county's policy regarding sexual harassment: (1) It is illegal and against the policies of the county for any employee, male or female, to sexually harass another employee by: a. Making unwelcome sexual advances or requests for sexual favors or other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature a condition of an employee's continued employment. b. Making submission to or rejections of such conduct the basis for employment decisions affecting the employee. c. Discriminating against an employee because of his sex. Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment. (2) No person shall threaten or insinuate, either explicitly or implicitly, that an employee's refusal to submit to sexual advances will adversely affect the employee's employment, evaluation, wages, advancement, assigned duties, shifts or any other condition of employment or career development. (3) It is the responsibility of each supervisor, department director and elected official having adopted this policy to maintain the workplace free of sexual harassment. This duty includes discussing this policy with all employees and assuring them that they are not to endure insulting, degrading or exploitive sexual treatment. (4) Any employee who believes he has been the subject of sexual harassment should report the alleged act immediately to his supervisor, department director, elected official or the director of personnel. Any supervisor, department director or elected official who becomes aware of or suspects sexual harassment shall immediately report such information to the director of personnel. Upon receiving a complaint, an investigation shall be undertaken immediately by the department/office in conjunction with the personnel office. Any employee who has been found after appropriate investigation to have sexually harassed another employee will be subject to disciplinary action by his department director or elected official from a written warning up to and including termination. (5) It is recognized that the question of whether a particular action or incident is a purely personal, social relationship without discriminatory employment effect requires a factual determination based on all facts pertaining to the incident. Given the nature of this type of discrimination, it is further recognized that false accusations of sexual harassment can cause serious effects on innocent women and men. Accordingly, false accusations will result in severe disciplinary action up to and including termination. The county trusts that all employees will continue to act responsibly to establish a pleasant working environment free of sexual harassment. (Ord. No. 2002-13, § 56(70-197), 8-19-2002)

div.head: Chapter 36 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 36-1. - Athletic events upon roadways. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Athletic event means any game; sport; contest; practice or other activity, by one or more persons, involving any sport, including, but not limited to, football, basketball, baseball, softball, horseshoes, soccer, skateboarding, and rollerblading. Goal means any device, equipment or item used in any athletic event. Private roadway means any driveway or roadway, privately owned and/or maintained, connecting a development containing structures of more than one dwelling unit to a public roadway, directly or indirectly, normally used by motor vehicle traffic to reach the dwelling units from public roadways. Public roadway means any driveway or roadway maintained by the city, the county, or the state. Traffic obstruction means to impede, slow or stop motor vehicle or pedestrian traffic upon a private roadway or public roadway. (b) Goals attached to the principal residential structure or erected adjacent to and abutting the driveway of the principal residential structure shall be allowed in the front yard but not within the right-of-way of a public street or sidewalk. No such goal shall be erected in such a manner that the play area for the athletic event or goal is located within any portion of a public right-of-way. (c) Portable goals used for athletic events are allowed in the front yard but must be relocated to the side yard, rear yard, or placed inside the structure after use. (d) No goal, including portable goals shall be placed in the public street or right-of-way, nor will a goal be placed so that the public street or sidewalk is the court or playing surface for the athletic event. (e) Any goal or portable goal located within the public street or right-of-way is hereby declared a nuisance. After giving notice of the violation by posting a notice on the goal and sending a copy thereof by certified mail with return receipt requested to the address where the goal is located and giving ten calendar days after the notice has been posted to correct the deficiencies, the city shall have the authority to remove the nuisance objects and take it to the county landfill or such other place designated by the mayor and council. The expense of such action shall be charged against the property owner, become a lien on the property, and be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. The notice required by this subsection shall also be sent by first class mail to the last known address of the property owner if different from the resident. (f) If notice has been given by posting the illegally placed or by mail to a property owner or renter regarding the illegal placement of a goal on the public right-of-way within 24 months of a new or subsequent violation, the goal is to be removed from the public right-of-way without further notice, taken to the landfill and the cost for the removal will become a lien on the property to be collected by the same means, process and manner by which taxes are collected by the city. (g) It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in possession of the real property to allow a goal or portable goal to be located on the real property in violation of this section. (h) It shall be unlawful for any person participating in an athletic event to conduct that event on the public roadways or private roadways within the city in such a manner that pedestrian or vehicular traffic is obstructed, impeded, slowed or diverted, or that an unsafe condition is created creating a substantial risk to persons or property. Any law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer authorized to enforce the city's ordinances may issue a summons for any person violating this subsection without the notice requirements contained in the remainder of this section. (i) When a law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer of the city, authorized to enforce the city's ordinances, finds a violation of this section has occurred, a summons may be issued by such officer or designated employee to the owner or person in possession of the real property where the violation has occurred, and said owner or person in possession may be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or six months imprisonment, or both, except as otherwise provided by general law. The fines imposed therefor may be collected by execution. However, in no event shall the maximum penalties and punishment exceed a fine of $1,000.00 and an imprisonment for six months for any single offense. (Ord. No. 2008-10, § 1(62-207), 7-14-2008) Sec. 36-2. - Solicitation on the highways. (a) Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97.1, the mayor and council hereby declares it permissible at certain times and under certain circumstances for charitable organizations registered in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 43-17-5 and charitable organizations exempt from such registration to solicit contributions on the streets and highways within the city. Any charitable organization desiring to solicit contributions in accordance with this section shall file an application with the city or its designee and shall submit proper evidence of its registration or exemption, and otherwise comply with provisions of this section together with all other rules and regulations pertaining to or governing such solicitation activity. (b) Notwithstanding the issuance of any solicitation permit, the solicitation of contributions shall not take place on any portion of U.S. Highway 41/19 (Tara Boulevard) or state highway located in the city. Further, the solicitation of contributions shall not take place on any street or highway within the city between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. (Monday through Friday), and between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. (Monday through Friday). (Ord. No. 2002-07, § 8(94-6), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-3. - Fire, heat or pouring injurious substances prohibited on paved streets. It is unlawful to place any fire or other harmful hot material upon any city street, or to empty or pour upon the same any gasoline or other substance likely to injure the same. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 37(82-111), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-4. - Dragging or sliding objects on pavement. It is unlawful for any person to drag or slide any object across any of the paved streets of the city. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 38(82-112), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-5. - Sidewalks; construction to conform to grade; encroachment on sidewalks with structures. (a) It is unlawful for any person to grade, or otherwise work or construct a sidewalk within the city, unless such repair or construction is made according to a street-level survey, a diagram of which survey shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk, for public inspection. (b) It is unlawful for any person to encroach upon sidewalks with fences or other structures, without special permission from the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 39(82-113), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-6. - Gates and doors; swinging across sidewalk prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to permit any gate or door to be so mounted, or hung, as to swing or slide over, on or across any portion of a sidewalk or street when opened. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 40(82-114), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-7. - Damages to public roads; contractor's responsibility. (a) Prior to an occupancy permit being issued for a development by the city or its designee, the city or its designee shall certify in writing that no damage has been done to the public roads of the city that lie adjacent to the property upon which the construction has occurred due to such construction activity. (b) If construction activity has resulted in damage to the public roads of the city that are adjacent to the property upon which construction work has occurred, the party seeking the permit shall first pay the actual cost of all damages to the public roads to the city prior to obtaining the permit. (c) Any contractor whose activity has resulted in damage to streets adjacent to the construction site, who fails or refuses to pay for same, may be prosecuted in the city court. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 41(82-115), 5-20-2002) Secs. 36-8—36-32. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UTILITY INSTALLATIONS IN PUBLIC ROADWAYS
Sec. 36-33. - Violation; penalty. Any person who shall violate the terms of this article, or who shall excavate or cut any public road in the city without first obtaining a permit therefor, may be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-11. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 4(82-26), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-34. - Permit. (a) Any person shall obtain a permit prior to the installation, construction, maintenance, renewal, removal and relocation of pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers, drains or appliances of any utility in, on, along, over or under the public roads of the city. (b) Application for the permit required by this section shall be made in writing to the city or its designee, including the county director of transportation and development. Such application shall specifically describe the nature, extent and location of the portion of the public roads affected. As a condition precedent to the granting of a permit, the city or its designee, including the county engineer, may require the applicant to furnish an indemnity bond or other acceptable security conditioned to pay any damages to any part of the city road system or to any member of the public caused by work of the applicant under authority of such permit. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 5(82-27), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-35. - Traffic regulation while work in progress. While work is in progress, it shall be the duty and the responsibility of the applicant to ensure that the work performed under authority of the permit does not unreasonably interfere with the use of the city road system. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to provide adequate, safe and competent traffic control at all times and to maintain adequate signal or warning devices necessary to protect the traveling public. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 5(82-28), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-36. - Refilling and repairing. It shall be the duty and the responsibility of the applicant for the permit, after having made any excavation or cut in any public road of the city, to refill the same to the specifications of the city or its designee, including the county director of transportation, and all applicable city regulations. The cost of restoring any such excavated public road to its former condition shall be paid by the person making or causing such excavation. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 6(82-29), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-37. - Removal and relocation of utilities at direction of city. Any utility using or occupying any part of a public road which the city has undertaken to improve or intends to improve shall remove and relocate its facility when in the reasonable opinion of the city or its designee, including the county director of transportation, the facility constitutes an obstruction or interference with the use or safe operation of such road by the traveling public or when in the reasonable opinion of the city or its designee, including the county engineer, the facility will interfere with such contemplated construction or maintenance. Any such removal or relocation shall be at the expense of the utility, and at no expense to the city or its designee. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 6(82-30), 5-20-2002) Secs. 36-38—36-62. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STREET LIGHTING
Sec. 36-63. - Establishment of districts—Filing petition. Property owners residing in any incorporated area in the city desiring street lighting for the area in which they live may petition the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineering department, to have such services. Such petition must contain not less than ten property owners representing not less than 50 percent of the property owners within the district to be established. A petition may be brought by less than ten property owners where such represents 100 percent of the property owners within the district to be established. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 9(82-51), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-64. - Establishment of districts—Public hearing on petition. After investigation by the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineering department, as to advisability of establishing a district under this article, the petition shall be presented to the mayor and council for consideration upon a public hearing. After the public hearing, the petition will be either approved or disapproved by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 9(82-52), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-65. - Standard for installation and operation adopted by reference; compliance. The American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting, as sponsored by the Illuminating Engineering Society and approved by the American Standards Association on July 11, 1973, is hereby adopted as the standard for installation and operation of street and roadway lighting in the incorporated areas of the city. A copy of these standards shall be on file with the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineer. Lighting fixtures installed within the public rights-of-way to be operated for the purpose of street illumination shall comply with these standards. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 10(82-53), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-66. - Procedure for approval of proposed lighting within public rights-of-way; installation of security lights, etc., within public rights-of-way; installation of other lights within public rights-of-way. (a) Any party requesting permission to install or operate lighting fixtures within the public rights-of-way shall furnish plans and specifications to the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineer, for approval showing how the proposed lighting meets the standards, and no lighting shall be installed or operated without such approval. Should the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineer, disapprove the request to install or operate lighting fixtures within any public rights-of-way because of the failure to meet standards, such disapproval shall be communicated in writing to the party requesting same. Such written communication shall include the specific reasons for disapproval. Any disapproval of a light or lighting system by the city's designee, including the county traffic engineer, may be appealed to the mayor and council. If any party desires to appeal an adverse decision by the city's designee, including the county traffic engineer, a notice of appeal shall be filed with the designee within 30 days from the date following the written notice of disapproval, and it shall be the responsibility of the designee to transmit forthwith to the mayor and council all papers and allied documents constituting the record upon which the action appealed was taken and to ensure that such appeal is promptly placed upon the agenda of the mayor and council for its determination. The mayor and council may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, require, decision or determination appealed from. (b) Roadway or street lighting luminaries or fixtures installed within the public rights-of-way as security lights, or for the purpose of lighting areas other than the public streets, shall be mounted on the side of the pole opposite from such street and shall be oriented in such a manner as to ensure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street and the vertical light distribution, at the initial light source, is perpendicular to the street, so as to protect the users of the street from objectionable glare. The approval of the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineer, shall be obtained before installation of such lights. (c) Other lighting fixtures to be installed within or outside of public rights-of-way for whatever purpose shall be installed and operated in such a manner as to prevent glare from being a hazard to, or interfering with, the normal use of the public rights-of-way. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 11(82-54), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-67. - Approval of proposed lighting installations within public rights-of-way required; installation of security lights, etc., on public rights-of-way; submission of plans and specifications for lighting fixtures in public rights-of-way. The installation and operation of lighting fixtures located within the rights-of-way of any public street, road, highway, sidewalk or alley in the incorporated areas of the city, or fixed to any pole, lamppost, standard or other supporting device which is located within such rights-of-way, will follow the following procedures: (1) Plans and specifications for the proposed installation showing compliance with these standards will be submitted to the city or its designee, including the county traffic engineer for approval. No installations will be made without this approval. (2) Fixtures for illuminating areas adjoining the public streets, roads, etc., such as parking areas, driveways, etc., will be mounted in such a manner as to ensure that the light pattern is kept off the public roadway. When street or roadway lighting luminaries are to be used for security lighting, they will be mounted on the side of the pole that is opposite from the public street and will be mounted to ensure that the lateral light distribution pattern is parallel to the street and the vertical light distribution at the initial light source is perpendicular to the street. (3) If lighting fixtures of a type other than those in the classification of street or roadway luminaries are to be used or if the proposed lighting is to be for other than drives, parking areas or other similar area lighting, the plans and specifications submitted will be sufficiently detailed to clearly show that such a proposal is in compliance with these standards and will not cause a hazard to, or interfere with, the normal use of the public streets, roads or highways. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 12(82-55), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-68. - Service rates—Establishment; amendment. The rates established for the provision and maintenance of street lights within the city shall be set by the mayor and council or its designee, including the county traffic engineering department. These rates will be subject to change to reflect future rate increases to the city and shall not be less than the charges to the city. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 13(82-56), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-69. - Service rates—Basis for determination. Rates shall be based upon frontage of property. Frontage will apply to street frontage toward which the house, home, building or dwelling fronts. Side yards will not be charged. Each platted lot, whether developed or not, will be subject to the assessment charges. Industrial and commercial area street-lighting rates will be determined by the number and kind of street lights necessary to meet the American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting standards. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 14(82-57), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-70. - Service rates—Collection; enforcement as lien. The rates or charges for street light service shall constitute assessments on the property so serviced. These assessments shall be added to tax bills at the end of each year and shall constitute a lien upon the property serviced. Such lien shall have the same priority as tax assessments. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 15(82-58), 5-20-2002) Secs. 36-71—36-98. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SPEED HUMPS
Sec. 36-99. - Purpose. In response to an increasing number of complaints regarding speeding problems in residential neighborhoods, the city and its designee, including the county department of transportation (the department), has studied available alternatives and methods employed by other similarly situated communities and how effectively and successfully those communities have addressed residential speeding problems. The installation of speed humps was found to be a popular and relatively cost effective measure in reducing average speeds. When properly designed and installed, and with strong majority community backing and support, speed humps were found to be effective at reducing speeds in neighborhoods. After much experimenting and testing, including testing on city and county roads, the use of speed humps has been widely endorsed by transportation authorities. In the United States, a policy on the use of speed humps has been developed by a special committee of the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE). As a result of these preliminary efforts, the following procedures have been established for groups of citizens in the city who want to pursue the installation of speed humps in their neighborhoods. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 18(82-71), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-100. - Criteria for installation. The city will consider the installation of speed humps only on streets classified as local residential streets. Traffic studies must find that a speeding problem exists sufficient to warrant installation of one or more speed humps. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 19(82-72), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-101. - Request for study; public hearing. An authorized officer of an organized homeowners association or the majority of homeowners within a neighborhood may, through an informal petition or letter, request that a neighborhood be studied for speed hump installation. The letter or petition must demonstrate that the desires of a majority of the property owners in that neighborhood are represented. The results of the neighborhood traffic speed study may be directed to the neighborhood representative by certified mail or, upon request, will be presented by the city or its designee to a neighborhood at a public hearing organized, arranged, and publicized by the neighborhood group along with a general presentation on speed humps. All property owners in the neighborhood shall be notified by an authorized representative of the neighborhood group of the time and place of the public hearing. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 20(82-73), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-102. - Petition for installation—Preparation. A formal petition in such form as prescribed by the city or its designee shall be filed requesting that one or more speed humps be installed within a neighborhood. All property owners in the neighborhood shall be notified by an authorized representative of the neighborhood group and afforded an opportunity to sign the petition. Each property owner shall indicate his preference for the installation of neighborhood speed humps by marking a "YES" or "NO" on the petition. If more than one person owns the property, all parties shall sign the petition individually to be counted. Renting tenants are not an acceptable substitute for the legal property owner and may not sign petitions as related to this program. No valid signature will be withdrawn from the petition after it is filed with the city. Each person signing the petition shall sign before a witness who shall be available to verify the signature of a property owner. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 21(82-74), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-103. - Petition for installation—Number of signatures required; filing. At least 75 percent of the property owners in a neighborhood must indicate an affirmative preference for speed humps before a petition will be considered by the city. The percentages shall be calculated by dividing the total number of property owners by the total number of property owners indicating an affirmative preference. For the purposes of determining the number of property owners in the neighborhood, the geographical boundaries of the neighborhood shall be established using the database of applicable taxing authorities. In the event a neighborhood is not completely built out, a minimum of 30 percent of the total number of residences must be occupied before a petition for the installation of speed humps will be considered. The completed petition must state the name and address of the representative of the neighborhood group, it must be signed by the representative before a notary public and returned to the department where it will be checked against property tax records to ensure that all requirements are met. Those petitions failing to meet specified requirements will be returned to the representative for compliance. Petitions meeting all requirements will be presented for approval or disapproval by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 22(82-75), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-104. - Construction; warnings posted. (a) The geometric design of speed humps has been proven to be a critical factor in terms of their safety and effectiveness in lowering speeds. Based on extensive research, speed humps shall be constructed with the following specifications: Four inches maximum vertical rise, 22 feet in horizontal length, and incline-flattop-decline. (b) Each individual speed hump location shall require posting of standard warning signs that will be installed along the back of the curb within the city-owned rights-of-way. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 23(82-76), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-105. - Procedure for removal. The city may remove speed humps under the following conditions: (1) A formal petition in the form as prescribed in section 36-102 shall be filed with the city indicating that 75 percent of the property owners request the removal of the speed humps; (2) The petition shall contain a statement acknowledging that the property owners are aware of the probability that vehicular traffic speeds within the neighborhood may increase after the speed humps are removed; (3) The speed humps shall not have been installed less than one year from the date of receipt of the petition; and (4) All costs associated with the initial installation and removal of the speed humps, as determined and itemized by the city or its designee, shall have been paid. In the event a neighborhood is not completely built out, a minimum of 60 percent of the total number of residences must be occupied before a petition or the removal of speed humps will be considered. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 24(82-77), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-106. - Charges for installation, maintenance, and removal; length of time for installation. All property owners in a petitioning neighborhood shall pay for the installation and maintenance of the speed humps. The annual charge associated with the initial installation, maintenance, and repair of speed humps shall be as established by the city and amendable by resolution. The charge associated with the removal of speed humps shall be at a level that adequately covers the cost of removal as determined by the city or its designee. All rates may be subject to change to reflect material and labor increases to the city. The installation of the speed humps may be completed, weather permitting, in approximately four months or less from the date the petition is approved by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 25(82-78), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-107. - Collection; enforcement as a lien. The charges for installation, maintenance, and removal of speed humps shall be in the form of an assessment against the property and shall be itemized as a separate entry, and added annually to each property owner's property tax statement. The assessment shall constitute a lien upon the property and have the same priority as an ad valorem tax lien. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 26(82-79), 5-20-2002) Secs. 36-108—36-127. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - DISPOSSESSORIES
Sec. 36-128. - Intent. It is the intent of this article to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the traveling public in the city by providing the means by which personalty of dispossessed tenants will be removed from the city's right-of-way if otherwise left thereon for an unreasonable period of time. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 29(82-91), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-129. - Dispossessory bond required. Upon the receipt of a writ of possession issued by a court for execution, local law enforcement officials shall inquire of the property owner or his agent, if any (landlord), if, in addition to placing the landlord in possession of the premises, the landlord desires the personalty of the tenant be removed to the city's right-of-way. If the answer is in the affirmative, the sheriff shall require evidence that the landlord has posted a cash bond with the city or its designee in the amount established by the city and amendable by resolution. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 30(82-92), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-130. - Claim against dispossessory bond. In the event the personalty of a dispossessed tenant remains on the city's right-of-way for a period of 24 hours, the landlord, at his own expense, shall cause the personalty to be removed from the city's right-of-way. In the event the landlord fails to remove the personalty within the time prescribed, the county may cause such personalty to be removed to the county landfill, and thereafter assert a claim against the landlord's bond to the extent of moving and disposal expenses. In the further event the landlord's bond is not sufficient to cover the expenses associated with the removal and disposal of the personalty, such lien may be claimed against the realty of the landlord, and thereafter foreclosed in the same manner as special liens on real estate by laborers in accordance with applicable state laws. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 31(82-93), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-131. - Additional remedies. It is the intent of this article to provide an additional or supplemental means of obtaining compliance with the removal of personalty of dispossessed tenants from the city's right-of-way. Nothing contained in this article shall abrogate the right of tenants to remove their own personalty from the city's right-of-way, nor the landlord's right to remove such personalty and thereafter proceed against the tenants for the recovery of expenses incurred therefor, nor of the right of the landlord to recover against the tenants such charges incurred by the landlord as a result of the city's removal and disposal of the tenants' personalty. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 32(82-94), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-132. - Property deemed to be abandoned. Property which has been set on the right-of-way of the city and remains there for a period in excess of 24 hours shall be presumed abandoned unless prior arrangements for claiming the property by the owner, his heirs or assigns has been received by the city or its designee, including the county department of refuse control. Such abandoned property shall be deemed to be a hazard and detrimental to the health, safety, and welfare of the traveling public in the city. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 33(82-95), 5-20-2002) Sec. 36-133. - Disposition of abandoned property. (a) Whenever it is brought to the attention of the city that abandoned property as provided in section 36-132 exists on the right-of-way, the city or its designee shall attempt to ascertain the name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the property. If such information is known, the owner of the property shall be contacted and advised to immediately abate the hazard by removing the property from the right-of-way. (b) In the event the personalty of a dispossessed tenant is set on the city's right-of-way at the insistence of the landlord, and such property thereafter is presumed abandoned, the landlord, at his own expense, shall cause the personalty to be removed from the city's right-of-way in accordance with provisions of section 36-130. (c) If the owner of the abandoned property cannot be located or attempts to contact such owner has failed, and the landlord, if applicable, fails to remove the abandoned property, the city may abate the hazard without the prior approval of the property owner. The city or its designee, including the county department of refuse control, is authorized to use work crews, private contractors, or any inmate labor to abate the hazard by removing the abandoned property to a landfill in accordance with provisions of section 36-130. (Ord. No. 2002-06, § 34(82-96), 5-20-2002)

div.head: Chapter 38 - TAXATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 38-1. - Excise tax on motor vehicle rental charges. (a) The mayor and council hereby authorizes the levy and collection of an excise tax upon the rental charge collected by a rental motor vehicle concern when such charge constitutes a taxable event for the purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. title 48, ch. 8, art. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq.). The tax levied pursuant to this section shall be levied and collected at the rate of three percent of the rental charges. The tax levied pursuant to this section shall be imposed only at the time when and place where a customer pays sales tax with respect to the rental charge. The customer who pays a rental charge that is subject to this tax levied shall be liable for the tax. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern. The tax shall be a debt of the customer to the rental motor vehicle concern until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts. The rental motor vehicle concern collecting the tax shall remit the tax to the city, and the tax remitted shall be a credit against the tax imposed on the rental motor vehicle concern. Every rental motor vehicle concern subject to this tax levied shall be liable for the tax at the applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of taxes collected from the customers, whichever is greater. (b) The mayor and council hereby declares that the proceeds of the tax are to be expended and shall apply in each fiscal year during which the tax is collected for capital outlay projects pertaining to the construction of the city's parks and recreational facilities, and maintenance and operation expenses associated with such recreational facilities. (c) The tax levied pursuant to this section shall terminate not later than December 31, 2038. (Ord. No. 2001-22, § 3(90-1), 12-17-2001) Secs. 38-2—38-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EXEMPTIONS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 38-21. - Annually set. The ad valorem tax rate for each year shall be established annually by the city council by resolution supported by a majority vote and entered on the minutes. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1(90-100), 10-8-2012) Sec. 38-22. - Due date. (a) All ad valorem taxes due the city on all property in the city subject to taxation shall be due and payable annually on December 20. Any such tax not paid by December 20 shall be declared delinquent. Delinquent taxes shall accrue interest at the highest legal rate per annum authorized by state law from December 20 to the date payment is made. Should the city provide for any installment plans, said due dates shall not apply and persons eligible for installment payment plans will be notified of the new due dates. Installment payment plans shall be at the discretion of mayor and council or those persons appointed by the mayor and council to render such decision. Penalties and interest shall not apply to those persons allowed to pay taxes through a city-authorized installment payment plan. (b) For those persons not enrolled in a city-authorized installment payment plan, any payment of ad valorem taxes due to the city that is not paid on or before the delinquency date shall be in default, and shall bear interest and penalties, now or hereafter, as provided by law for taxes which are delinquent or in default, and executions shall be issued therefor, at such time the city has met the legal requirements of all state and local laws. (c) The penalty for delinquent taxes shall be ten percent of the base amount of the taxes due. Said penalty shall be in addition to the amount of ad valorem taxes due the city and also in addition to any costs and interest permitted by law. (d) In addition to said penalty, interest shall accrue on such unpaid taxes at the rate of one percent per month beginning on January 20 following the December when such taxes were due and continuing thereafter until paid in full. All interest shall be computed at the rate of one percent per month of the base amount or for any fraction thereof. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1(90-101), 10-8-2012) Sec. 38-23. - Collection of delinquent taxes. (a) For the collection of delinquent taxes, a fi. fa. shall be issued by the city clerk and executed by the chief of police under the procedure provided by the laws of the state governing execution of process from the superior court, or by use of any other available process and remedies. (b) A lien shall exist against all property on which city property taxes are levied, as of the assessment day of January 1 of each year, which shall be superior to all other liens except that it shall have equal dignity with those for federal, state, county or city taxes. (c) The amount due on all delinquent fi. fas. issued under subsection (a) of this section, as well as any interest or penalty thereon, shall be listed as a part of and in addition to the annual ad valorem tax bill. (d) Any license, privilege or permit granted by the city shall be revoked by the city clerk for the failure to pay any money due the city for taxes, fees, penalties, interest, fines or other revenue, within one month after any payment is due; provided, however, that any person aggrieved by the order may, within ten days thereof, appeal to the city council, who, after a hearing thereon, may approve or modify the order or restore the license, privilege or permit by adopting a motion to that effect but only upon finding that the city clerk's action was not factually or legally correct. (e) Unless otherwise provided in this article, all fi. fas. issued under this article shall earn interest at the maximum rate allowed by state law. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1(90-102), 10-8-2012) Sec. 38-24. - Assessment of property for ad valorem taxes. (a) The county board of tax assessors is hereby designated to have the responsibility for assessment and valuation of property within the city limits. The city council shall adopt the assessments and valuations made by the board of tax assessors of the county for all property located within the city limits, as may be established from year to year by the county board of tax assessors. (b) The mayor and council authorizes the county tax commissioner to make such adjustments in the collection of individual items of tax, and to make such refunds as may be proper and necessary, by adding to or deducting from the distribution due the city at the next period of accounting, along with a stated explanation of the correction. (Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1(28-24), 10-8-2012) Secs. 38-25—38-51. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - MANUFACTURED GOODS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Freeport exemptions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48.1 et seq.
Sec. 38-52. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Finished goods means goods, wares, and merchandise of every character and kind, but shall not include unrecovered, unextracted or unsevered natural resources, or raw materials, or goods in the process of manufacture or production, or the stock-in-trade of a retailer. Raw materials means any materials, whether crude or processed, that can be converted by manufacture, processing, or combination thereof, into a new and useful product, but shall not include unrecovered, unextracted or unsevered natural resources. (Ord. No. 2001-22, § 7(90-36), 12-17-2001) Sec. 38-53. - Amount; effective date, duration; requirements. Upon proper request by the taxpayers at or before the time of making their tax returns on certain tangible personal properties, the taxpayers will be exempt from ad valorem taxes on 100 percent of all the value of such tangible personal properties as it relates to ad valorem taxes for city purposes. This exemption shall become effective beginning January 1, 1987, and each succeeding year pending further action by the mayor and council, provided the above procedure requesting exemption is followed annually. Those properties are as follows: (1) Inventory of goods in the process of manufacture or production, which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in this state. (2) Inventory of finished goods manufactured or produced within the state in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business, when held by the original manufacturer or producer of such finished goods. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is produced or manufactured. (3) Inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, and which are destined for shipment to a final destination outside the state and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside this state and stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in this state. All property that is claimed to be exempt under the provisions of this section shall be designated as being in transit upon the official books and records of the warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, where such property is being stored. Such official books and records shall contain a full, true and accurate inventory of all such property, including the date of the receipt of the property, the date of the withdrawal of the property, the point of origin of the property, and the point of final destination of the same, if known. The official books and records of any such warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, pertaining to any such in transit property shall be at all times open to the inspection of all taxing authorities of this state and of any political subdivision of this state. (Ord. No. 2001-22, § 7(90-37), 12-17-2001) Sec. 38-54. - Administration. The tax assessor's office shall provide the necessary administrative action, materials and personnel in order to effect an orderly administration of this tax exemption according to the laws of the state, and shall provide the necessary forms, formats, and other related materials for the taxpayers in making their claims for such exemption. The tax commissioner's office shall take notice of the results of the September 27, 1979, election approving this tax exemption, of the resolution from which this section is derived, and of the actions of the tax assessor's office, in carrying out the administrative functions of its office. (Ord. No. 2001-22, § 7(90-38), 12-17-2001) Secs. 38-55—38-81. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BUSINESS AND OCCUPATIONAL TAXES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local business taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq.
Sec. 38-82. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any business, profession, occupation, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses, trades, occupations, and professions which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-28. All other applicable businesses, trades, occupations and professions are taxed by the city pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1(22-1), 7-21-2003) Sec. 38-83. - Occupation tax required for business dealings in the city. For the year 2004 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a fixed business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no fixed business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the occupation tax clerk or that officer's deputies or to any enforcement officer of the city, upon request. However, for practitioners of professions and occupations, display of such tax registration shall not be a prerequisite to practice their professions. In the event a business or other entity licensed under this section is sold, without ceasing business within the city, curing the period in which a valid license is issued for that period and all taxes and fees are current, the new owner shall not be required to pay occupational taxes for the remainder of that license year. The new owner will be responsible for all application fees. (Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1(22-2), 7-21-2003; Ord. No. 08-15, § 1(22-2), 10-13-2008) Sec. 38-83.1. - General proration of fees. (a) Any fee for a business or occupation shall be prorated so that if the initial application for the business is received in the calendar months of January, February and March, the entire fee shall be collected. If the initial application for a business is received in the months of April, May or June, three-quarters of the administrative fee shall be collected by the city. If the initial application is received during the months of July, August or September, one-half of the administrative fee shall be collected by the city. If the initial application is received during the months of October, November or December, one-quarter of the administrative fee shall be collected by the city. (b) All other occupational taxes and fees provided under this Code shall remain unaffected by the provision of this section. (c) Any fee assessed under this Code for a background investigation for applications for a business license, permit, occupation or profession shall not be prorated and shall remain unaffected by this section. (d) No occupational tax, fee or license based upon gross receipts shall be prorated unless specifically provided for in this Code. (Ord. No. 08-15, § 1(22-2.1), 10-13-2008) Sec. 38-84. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a fee which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax application. Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for the purposes of documenting compensation a Form IRS W-2, but not a Form IRS 1099. An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual for the purposes of documenting compensation a Form IRS W-2. Gross receipts. (1) The term "gross receipts" means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without being limited to the following: a. Total income without deduction for the cost of goods sold or expenses incurred; b. Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; c. Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; d. Proceeds from fees charged for services rendered; e. Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income. (2) The term "gross receipts" shall not include the following: a. Sales, use, or excise taxes; b. Sales returns, allowances, and discounts; c. Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations, as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(2), between or among a parent corporation, wholly owned subsidiaries of such parent corporation, and any corporation in which such parent corporation or one or more of its wholly owned subsidiaries owns stock possessing at least 30 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of stock of such partially owned corporation, or between or among wholly owned partnerships or other wholly owned entities; d. Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent for services which contributed to the gross receipts in issue; e. Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds, received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organizations receipts; f. Proceeds from sales of goods or services delivered to or received by customers located outside the state at the time of delivery or receipt. Location or office means and includes any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. A renters or lessees location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. Nonprofit organization means any entity that is exempt from paying income taxes to the state on gross receipts or other income. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue-raising purposes. Person means and includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes all nonprofit organizations. Practitioner of a profession or occupation means one, who by state law, requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation as designated by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c), but shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The term "regulatory fees" does not include development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development. (Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1(22-3), 7-21-2003) State Law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. Sec. 38-85. - Administrative fee.
